[ 1. Introduction]

śrī gaṇeśāya namaḥ// atha rājayogaprakāro likhyate/ rājayogasyedaṃ phalaṃ/ yena rājayogenānekarājyabhogasamaya eva/ anekapārthivavinoda prekṣaṇasamaya eva/ bahutarakālaṃ śarīrasthitir bhavati/ sa eva rājayogaḥ/ tasyaite bhedāḥ/ cf. YSv (PT p. 831): pañcadaśaprakāro 'yaṃ rājayogaḥ || kriyāyogo jñānayogaḥ karmayogo haṭhas tathā | dhyānayogo mantrayoga urayogaś ca vāsanā | rājaty etad brahmavaśīva ebhiś ca pañcadaśadhā | idānīṃ lakṣaṇañ caiṣāṃ kathayāmi śṛṇu priye | cf. Yogasiddhāntacandrikā (Ed. p. 2): nididhyāsanañ caika tānatādirūpo rājayogāparaparyāyaḥ samādhiḥ | tatsādhanaṃ tu kriyāyogaḥ, caryāyogaḥ, karmayogo, haṭhayogo, mantrayogo, jñānayogaḥ, advaitayogo, lakṣyayogo, brahmayogaḥ, śivayogaḥ, siddhiyogo, vāsanāyogo, layayogo, dhyānayogaḥ, premabhaktiyogaś ca |kriyāyogaḥ 1// jñānayogaḥ 2// caryāyogaḥ 3// haṭhayogaḥ 4// karmayogaḥ 5// layayogaḥ 6// dhyānayogaḥ 7// mantrayogaḥ 8// lakṣyayogaḥ 9// vāsanāyogaḥ 10// śivayogaḥ 11// brahmayogaḥ 12// advaitayogaḥ 13// siddhayogaḥ 14// rājayogaḥ 15// ete pañcadaśayogāḥ//

śrī gaṇeśāya namaḥ (ceteri) ] śrī ṇe ya maḥ (P), śrī gaṇeśāya namaḥ || śrī gurave namaḥ || (N1), śrī gaṇeśāya namaḥ || śrī sarasvatyai namaḥ || śrī nirañjanāya namaḥ || (D), śrī gaṇeśāya namaḥ || oṃ śrī niraṃjanāya || (U1)
atha rājayogaprakāro likhyate (N1 N2 D) ] atha rājayogaprakāra likhyate (U1), rājayogāntargataḥ || binduyogaḥ (E), atha tattvabiṃduyogaprāraṃbhaḥ (L), atha rājayoga liṣyate (P), atha rājayoga likhyate (U2)
rājayogasyedaṃ phalaṃ (P U2) ] rājayogasya idaṃ phalaṃ (N1 N2 D), om. (E L)
yogenāneka (P N1) ] °yogena aneka° (D N2 U1 U2)
prekṣaṇasamaya (ceteri) ] prekṣyaṇasamaya (U2)
eva (ceteri) ] evaṃ (U2)
rājayogaḥ (ceteri) ] rājayogas (U2)
tasyaite (P U2) ] tasya ete (ceteri)
caryāyogaḥ (ceteri) ] tvaryāyogaḥ (U1)
layayogaḥ (ceteri) ] nayayogaḥ (U2)
lakṣyayogaḥ (ceteri) ] lakṣayogaḥ (U1)
siddhayogaḥ (P U2) ] rājayogaḥ (X)
rājayogaḥ (P U2) ] siddhayogaḥ (ceteri)
ete pañcadaśayogāḥ (D N1 P U1) ] evaṃ paṃcadaśāyogā bhavaṃti (U2)

The initial codification of fifteen yogas appears in englishN1, englishN2, englishP, englishD, englishU1 and englishU2. It is ommitted in englishE, englishL and englishB (missing folio). It is also absent in the Yogasaṃgraha.

\vfill \nolinenumbers \smallskip [ 2. Kriyāyoga] \linenumbers

idānīṃ kriyāyogasya lakṣaṇaṃ kathyate/

idānīṃ (ceteri) ] idānī (N2), atha (U2)
kriyāyogasya (ceteri) ] kriyāyogas (U2)
kathyate (ceteri) ] kathayate (D), om. (U2)

\approx YSv (PT p. 831): kriyāmuktimayo (kriyāmuktir ayaṃ YK 1.209) yogaḥ sapiṇḍisiddhidāyakaḥ (sapiṇḍe YK 1.210) | yat kāromīti saṅkalpaṃ kāryārambhe manaḥ sadā ||kriyāmuktir ayaṃ yogaḥ svapiṇḍe siddhidāyakaḥ/ yaṃ yaṃ karoti kallolaṃ kāryāraṃbhe manaḥ sadā/ \approx YSv (PT p. 839): tatsāṅgācaraṇaṃ kurvan kriyāyogarato bhavet |tattataḥ kuñcanaṃ kurvan kriyāyogas taato bhavet// 2 .1 //

kriyāmuktir a (ceteri) ] kriyāmukti (N2), kriyāmuktiḥ || (U2)
yaṃ (ceteri) ] layaṃ (N2)
yogaḥ (ceteri) ] yogaḥ | (N1 U1)
siddhidāyakaḥ (ceteri) ] siddhidāyakaṃ (U2)
tattataḥ (ceteri) ] tatas tataḥ (U2), taṃkṛ taṃ (U1)
kuñcanaṃ (ceteri) ] kūrcanaṃ (N2)
ato bhavet (P U2) ] ato bhava (D N1 N2), ato va (U1)

[ 1. Introduction]

Homage to Śrī Gaṇeśa. Now the methods of Rājayoga are written down. This is the result of RājayogaThis statement seems unconnected to the definition of Rājayoga that follows.: Rājayoga is that by which long term durability of the body arises [and] even amongst manifold royal pleasures even amongst the manifold royal entertainments and spectacle.The definition of Rājayoga alludes to the exceptionally wealthy lifestyle of Rāmacandra's audience. This truly is Rājayoga. These are the varieties of this Rājayoga: \indent 1. The Yoga of [mental] action (Kriyāyoga); 2. the Yoga of knowledge (Jñānayoga); 3. the Yoga of wandering (Caryāyoga);The first three Yogas allude to the four pādas of the Śaiva āgamas; namely kriyā[pāda], caryā[pāda], yoga[padā] and jñāna[pāda], see nishvasa2015. 4. the Yoga of force (Haṭhayoga); 5. the Yoga of deeds (Karmayoga); 6. the Yoga of absorption (Layayoga); 7. the Yoga of meditation (Dhyānayoga); 8. the Yoga of Mantras (Mantrayoga); 9. the Yoga of targets (Lakṣyayoga); 10. Yoga of mental residues (Vāsanāyoga); 11. the Yoga of Śiva (Śivayoga); 12. the Yoga of Brahman (Brahmayoga); 13. the Yoga of non duality (Advaitayoga); 14. the Yoga of the Siddhas (Siddhayoga); 15. the Yoga of kings (Rājayoga). These are the fifteen Yogas.The definitive source of the list of the fifteen Yogas presented at the beginning of the text is uncertain. Rāmacandra's text is largely based on the content and structure of the Yogasvarodaya (YSv) as quoted in ramatosana (Ed. pp. 831 858). In this text, however, the list is incomplete. YSv mentions the total amount of fifteen Yogas but names only eight subcategories of Rājayoga. Because of that, Rāmacandra might have seen the necessity to complete it. The other source he used for compiling his text is ssplonavla (SSP) which, however, does not present such a list. A more detailed investigation of the fifteen Yogas can be found at p. . [ 2. Kriyāyoga] \indent Now, the characteristic of Kriyāyoga, the Yoga of [mental] action, is described. 2.1 This Yoga is liberation through [mental] action. It bestows success(siddhi) in one's own body. Each wave the mind creates at the beginning of an action, of all those, one shall withdraw oneself. Then Kriyāyoga arises.All four verses on Kriyāyoga were taken from the Yogsavarodaya (YSv) as quotations in the Prāṇatoṣinī (PT) and Yogakarṇikā (YK). No sources for the following prose section can be identified.

= YSv (PT p. 831): kṣamāvivekavairāgyaśāntisantoṣanispṛhāḥ | etan muktiyuto yo 'sau (muktiyutaś cāsau YK 1.211) kriyāyogo nigadyate |kṣamāvivekavairāgyaṃśāntisantoṣanispṛhāḥ/ etad yuktiyuto yo 'sau kriyāyogī nigadyate// 2 .2 //

viveka (ceteri) ] vivekaṃ (E U2)
nispṛhāḥ (P) ] °nispṛhaḥ (D), °nispṛhā (E N1), °niṣpṛhā ||2|| (N2), °niṣpṛhī (U1), °niṣpṛhāḥ || (U2)
etad yu (E P U1) ] etat (D N1 N2 U2)
ktiyuto (ceteri) ] muktiyuto (U2)
yo 'sau (N2 U1) ] yogī (D E P N1 U2)

The text of the printed Edition (E) begins here.

= YSv (PT p. 831): mātsaryaṃ mamatā māyā hiṃsā ca madagarvitā | kāmaḥ krodho bhayaṃ lajjā lobho mohas tathā 'śuciḥ (śuciḥ YK 1.212) ||mātsaryaṃ mamatā māyā hiṃsā ca madagarvatā/ kāmakrodhau bhayaṃ lajjā lobhamohau tathā 'śuciḥ// 2 .3 //

mātsaryaṃ (E U1 U2) ] mātsarya (D N1 P)
hiṃsā ca (E) ] hiṃsāśā (ceteri), hiṃsāḥ || (N1)
krodhau (U1 U2) ] krodha° (E N1 P), °krodho (D)
'śuciḥ (ceteri) ] śuciḥ (E N2 U2)

= YSv (PT p. 831): rāgadveṣau ghṛṇālasyaśrāntidambhakṣamābhramāḥ (ghṛṇālasyaṃ bhrāntir dambho 'kṣamā bhramaḥ YK 1.213) | yasyai tāni na vidyante kriyāyogī sa ucyate ||rāgadveṣaughṛṇālasyaṃ bhrantir daṃbho kṣamā bhramaḥ/ yasyai tāni na vidyante kriyāyogī sa ucyate// 2 .4 //

rāgadveṣau (ceteri) ] rāgadoṣau (U1), atha dveṣo (L)
ghṛṇā (ceteri) ] ghṛnā° (N2)
bhrantir daṃbho (ceteri) ] bhrāṃtir debho (D), bhrāntitvaṃ (E), bhrāṃti daṃbha° (U1)
kṣamā bhramaḥ (ceteri) ] mokṣam ābhramaḥ (E), kṣamī bhramaḥ (U1)
na (ceteri) ] ca (E)

The text of manuscript L begins here.

yasyāntaḥkaraṇe kṣamāvivekavairāgyaśāntisantoṣa ityādīny utpādyante/ sa eva bahukriyāyogī kathyate/ \approx (Yogasaṃgraha IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. ll. 1 2): lobhamohau aśucitvaṃ rāgadveṣau ālasyaṃ pāṣaṃḍitvaṃ bhrāṃtiḥ iṃdryiavikāraḥ kāmaḥ ete yasya pratidinaṃ nyunā bhavaṃti |kāpaṭyaṃ// māyā// vittaṃ// hiṃsā// tṛṣṇā// mātsaryaṃ// ahaṃkāraḥ// roṣaḥ// bhayaṃ// lajjā// lobhaḥ// mohaḥ// aśucitvaṃ// rāgaḥ// dveṣaḥ// ālasyaṃ// pākhaṃḍitvaṃ// bhrāntiḥ// indriyavikāraḥ// kāmaḥ// ete yasya manasi pradidinaṃ nyūna bhavanti/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. l. 2): sa eva kriyāyogī kathyate ||sa eva bahukriyāyogī kathyate/

kṣamā (ceteri) ] kṣamāḥ (N1), kṣamā ' (N2)
vivekavairāgyaśānti (ceteri) ] kṣamāḥ vivekavairāgya | śāṃti° (N1), °vairāgyāśānti° (N2), kṣamā || vivekavairāgya || śāṃti° (D)
santoṣa ityādīny u (ceteri) ] °santoṣādīny (E), °santoṣa ity ādīno° (L), °santoṣa ity ādīna niraṃtaram (U1), °santoṣa ity ādayo niraṃtaraṃ (U2)
tpādyante (ceteri) ] utpadyante (E), °tpādyaṃte (L), utyaṃte (U1)
bahukriyāyogī (ceteri) ] bahukriyāyogā (D)
kathyate (ceteri) ] sa kathyate (D N2), tkacyate (U2)
kāpaṭyaṃ (ceteri) ] kāpayaṃ (L), yasyāntaḥkaraṇe kapatyaṃ (N1), kāpachaṃ (U1)
māyā (N1 N2) ] māya (D), yāya (U1), pāpa (U2), om. (E P L)
vittaṃ (E P) ] vitaṃ (L), vitvaṃ (N1 N2 D U1), titaṃ (U2)
mātsaryaṃ (ceteri) ] mātsaryam (E), mātsarya (D U1)
roṣaḥ (E U1) ] roṣo (ceteri), eṣo (N2)
bhayaṃ (ceteri) ] kṣayaṃ (E)
lajjā (ceteri) ] lajā (U1)
lobhaḥ (P L) ] lobha° (ceteri), om. (U2)
mohaḥ (P) ] moha (L N2), mohā (ceteri)
aśucitvaṃ (ceteri) ] aśūcitvaṃ (N2)
rāgaḥ (P) ] rāga° (ceteri), rāja° (L), om. (E)
dveṣaḥ (ceteri) ] dveṣa (L), om. (E)
ālasyaṃ (ceteri) ] om. (E)
pākhaṃḍitvaṃ (ceteri) ] pāṣaṃḍitvaṃ (D N1), pākhaṃḍatvaṃ (E), pārṣaḍitvaṃ (N2)
indriyavikāraḥ (ceteri) ] iṃdriyaṃ vīkāraḥ (P), itivikāraḥ (L)
kāmaḥ (ceteri) ] kāma (N2), om. (U2)
ete (ceteri) ] eta (L), rāte (U1), etate (U2)
bhavanti (ceteri) ] bhavaīti (N1)
bahukriyāyogī (ceteri) ] bahukiyāyogī (D U1 U2)
kathyate (ceteri) ] kathyaṃte (U1 U2)

2.2 Patience, discrimination, equanimity, peace, modesty, desirelessness: the one endowed with these means is said to be a Kriyāyogī. 2.3 Envy, selfishness, cheating, violence, desire and intoxication, pride, lust, anger, fear, laziness, greed, error, and impurity. 2.4 Attachment and aversion, indignation and idleness, impatience, and dizzyness: Whoever does not experience these is called a Kriyāyogī. Patience, discrimination, equanimity, peace, contentment, etc., are generated in his mind. He alone is called a Yogī of many actions (bahukriyāyogī)The term bahukriyāyogī is only found in the Yogatattvabindu. It seems to be a neologism of Rāmacandra since the Yogasvarodaya and Yogasaṃgraha only use the word kriyāyogī in its passage on Kriyāyoga to denote its practitioner.. Fraud, illusion, property, violence, craving, envy, ego, anger, anxiety, shame, greed, error, impurity, attachment, aversion, idleness, heterodoxy, false view, affection of the senses, sexual desire: He who diminishes these from day to day in his mind, he alone is called a Yogī of many actions (bahukriyāyogī).The most notable mention of the term kriyāyoga appears in Pātañjalayogaśāstra or Yogasūtra 2.1 where it is defined as tapaḥsvādhyāyeśvarapraṇidhānāni kriyāyogaḥ || 2.1 || ( yogasutra) According to the introduction of this sūtra in the Vyāsabhāṣya, Kriyāyoga is presented as a means how someone with a distracted mind can also attain Yoga (vyutthitacitto 'pi yogayuktaḥ). Yoga, which for Patañjali is samādhi, shall be achieved by the three elements of Kriyāyoga, namely mental, moral, and physical austerity (tapas), repetition of mantras or study of sacred literature (svadhyāya) and surrender to god (īśvarapraṇidhāna). This trinity of means is supposed to destroy the impurities (kleśas) of citta. These are given in Pātanjalayogaśāstra 2.3 as ignorance (avidyā), egoism (asmitā), attachment (rāga), aversion (dveṣa) and fear of death (abhiniveśa), see ( yogasutra). All three terms of Patañjali's Kriyāyoga are absent in the Yogatattvabindu. Nevertheless, the individual elements of the kleśas, along with the aim to reduce these in the yogi's mind, can also be found in the Yogatattvabindu. Nārāyaṇatīrtha in this commentary on the Pātanjalayogaśāstra titled Yogasiddhāntacandrikā, who, like Rāmacandra uses a very similar list of fifteen Yogas (possible source for Rāmacandras fifteen Yogas), presents Kriyāyoga as the first item of his list and explains its purpose as the generation of samādhi and the reduction of kleśas ( yogacandrika). In contrast, the Kriyāyoga of Rāmacandra leads to Rājayoga, which he conceptualizes as bringing about the steadiness of the body.

[ 3. Siddhakuṇḍalinīyoga and Mantrayoga]

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. ll. 2 3): atha rājayogasya bhedau kathyete ||idānīṃ rājayogasya bhedāḥ kathyante/ ke te/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. l. 3): siddhakuṃḍaliyogaḥ mantrayogaś ceti |ekaḥ siddhakuṇḍalinīyogaḥ mantrayogaḥ cf. YSv (PT p. 831): jñānayogaṃ pravakṣyāmi tajjñānī śivatāṃ vrajet | paṭhanāt smaraṇād vyānān maṇḍanāt brahmasādhakaḥ | tad bhedasyaikasandhānam aṣṭaiśvaryamayo bhavet | tritīrthaṃ yatra nāḍī ca tripuṇyaṃ parameśvari | \ldots eṣo 'sya viśvarūpasya rājayogo mato budhaiḥ | viśeṣaṃ kathayiṣyāmi śṛṇu caikamanāḥ sati |amū rājayogau kathyete/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. ll. 3 4): mūlakandasthāne ekā tejomayā mahānāḍī vartate |mūlakandasthāne ekā tejorūpā mahānāḍī vartate/ cf. YSv (PT p. 831 832): mūlakande sthale caikā nāḍī tejasvatī parā (tejasvitāparā YK 1.246) | \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. l. 4): iyaṃ iḍāpiṃgalasuṣumnā bhedā tridhā | vāmabhāge caṃdrarūpā iḍā | dakṣiṇabhāge sūryarūpā piṃgalā |cf. YSv (PT p. 832): gudorddhe (gudordhve YK 1.247) sā tribhāgābhūdiḍā (tridhā bhūyādiḍāvāme YK 1.247) nāma śaśiprabhā | śaktirūpā mahānāḍī dhyānāt sarvārthadāyinī | dakṣiṇe 'pi kulākhyeti (piṅgalākhyeti YK 1.248) puṃrūpā sūryavigrahā |iyam ekā nāḍī iḍāpiṅgalāsuṣumṇān// etān bhedān prāpnoti/ vāmabhāge candrarūpā iḍā nāḍī vartate/ dakṣiṇabhāge sūryarūpā piṅgalā nāḍī vartate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. ll. 5 6): madhyamārge atisūkṣmā visataṃtusamākārā koṭividyutprabhā bhuktimuktipradā suṣumnā nāḍī vartate | yasyāḥ jñāne purusaḥ sarvajño bhavati |cf. YSv (PT p. 832): madhyabhāge suṣumnākhyā brahmaviṣṇuśivātmikā | śuddhacittena sā vijñā vidyutkoṭisamaprabhā | bhuktimuktipradā dhyānād aṇimādiguṇapradā|cf. SSP 2.26 (Ed. p. 38): mūlakandād daṇḍalagnāṃ brahmanāḍīṃ śvetavarṇāṃ brahmarandhraparyantaṃ gatāṃ saṃsmaret | tanmadhye kamalatantunibhāṃ vidyutkoṭiprabhām ūrdhvagāminīṃ tāṃ mūrtiṃ manasā lakṣayet | sarvasiddhipradā bhavati |madhyamārge 'tisūkṣmā padminī/ tantusamākārā koṭividyutsamaprabhā/ bhuktimuktidā śivarūpiṇī suṣumṇā nāḍī pravarttate/ 'syāṃ jñānotpattau satyāṃ sarvajño bhavati//

The indroductory sentence is omitted in englishU1.

Sentences unlikely to be authorial, but enriching, are included within the edition and marked in another colour.

[ 3. Siddhakuṇḍalinīyoga and Mantrayoga]

Now, varieties of Rājayoga are described. Which are these? One is Siddhakuṇḍalinīyoga [and oneThe use of the term siddhakuṇḍalinīyoga instead of siddhayoga as listed initially is surprising. Furthermore, this type of Yoga, listed as the second last item in the initial Yoga taxonomy, is introduced as the second type right after Kriyāyoga, the first item in both the initial list and the subsequent text. This raises further questions as the term kuṇḍaliṇī is not mentioned at all in the subsequent description of this type of Yoga. The relation between "Siddhakuṇḍalinīyoga" and "Mantrayoga" appears mysterious since only the relatively late witness englishU 2 provides some description of a specific type of Mantrayoga. The additional passages of witness U2, highlighted in blue, instructs the "recitation of the non recited" (ajapājapa) of the haṃsaḥ mantra, also called "non recitation" (ajapā) Gāyatrī, during meditation for almost each (seven out of nine) cakras. All witnesses except englishL ( englishL omits the term mantrayoga) preserve this reading, and the sentence that follows the term supports the reading of mantrayoga by the usage of dual forms. The Yogatattvabindu closely follows the structure and content of the Yogasvarodaya, as quoted with reference in Prāṇatoṣiṇī and Yogakarṇikā. However, the Yoga introduced in Yogasvarodaya at this point is jñānayoga and neither siddhakuṇḍalinīyoga nor mantrayoga are mentioned. Since all manuscripts preserve the strange reading, but only the context of englishU 2 the terminology makes sense, it must be assumed that the additional passages of englishU 2 might have been original. The seemingly ``additional'' material could be ``original'' material and was lost in the early transmission of the text. A related text, the sarada 25.37ab provides a possible explanation for the linking of the two types of Yoga: "The kuṇḍalī Śakti abides in the haṃsaḥ [and] supports the [individual] Self" (bibharti kuṇḍalī śaktir ātmānaṃ haṃsaṃ āśritā |), see saradatilakafull.] is Mantrayoga. These two Rājayogas are described [in the following]. At the location of the root bulbThe root bulb or kanda in yogic literature is usually located below the navel or near the perineum. For more details, see . Rāmacandra's concept of the kanda is identical to the one found in vivekamartandaolda 16 (ūrdhvaṃ meḍhrād adho nābheḥ kandayoniḥ khagāṇḍavat | tatra nāḍyaḥ samutpannāḥ sahasrāṇi dvisaptatiḥ ||) ``Above the penis and below the navel is the home of the kanda, which is [formed] like the egg of a bird. There, the 72000 channels originate.'' exists one major vessel in the form of energy. This single vessel reaches these openings, which are iḍā, piṅgalā and suṣumnā. On the left side is the iḍā channel, resembling the moon. On the right side exists the piṅgalā channel, resembling the sun. Within the middle path is a lotus pond being very subtle. [It is] made from a web of light [and it] shines like a thousand bolts of lightning. She emerges as the central channel assuming the form of benevolence (śiva), [and] is the bestower of enjoyment and liberation. While abiding in (satyāṃ) her, (asyāṃ) knowledge arises. The person becomes all knowing.

[ 4. First Cakra]

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. l. 6): atas taj jñānotpattāv upāyā ucyaṃte |cf. YSv (PT p. 832): suṣumnāntaḥ samāśritya navacakraṃ yathā śṛṇu | mūlādhāraṃ catuṣpatraṃ gudorddhe (gudordhve YK 1.250) varttate mahat | tanmadhye svarṇapīṭhe tu trikoṇaṃ maṇḍalaṃ (trikoṇamaṇḍalaṃ YK 1.251) param | tatra vahniśikhākārā mūrttiḥ sarvatra siddhidā | asyā dhyānaṃ manomadhye vinā pīṭhena (pāṭhena YK 1.252) vāṅmayam | sarvaśāstrāṇi saṅkarṣaṃ (saṃkarṣa YK 1.252) sadā sphurati yogavit |cf. SSP 2.1 (Ed. p. 29): piṇḍe navacakrāṇi | ādhāre brahmacakraṃ tridhāvartaṃ bhagamaṇḍalākāram | tatra mūlakandaḥ | tatra śaktiṃ pāvakākārāṃ dhyāyet | tatraiva kāmarūpapīṭhaṃ sarvakāmaphalapradaṃ bhavati |idānīṃ suṣumṇāyāṃ jñānotpattāv upāyāḥ kathyante/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. l. 7): gudamūlacakraṃ caturdalaṃ |ādau caturdalaṃ mūlacakraṃ vartate/ prathamaṃ ādhāracakraṃ/ gudā sthānaṃ// raktaṃvarṇaṃ// gaṇeśaṃ daivataṃ// siddhibuddhiśaktiṃ muṣako vāhanaṃ// kūrmaṛṣiḥ// ākuñcanaṃmudrā// apānavāyuḥ// ūrmī kalā// ojasvinī dhāraṇā// caturdaleṣu rajaḥsattvatamomanāṃsi// vaṃ śaṃ ṣaṃ saṃ// madhya:trikoṇe triśikhā// tanmadhye \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. l. 7): tanmadhye trikoṇākāraṃ kāmapiṭhaṃ |trikoṇākāraṃ kāmapiṭhaṃ vartate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. l. 7): tatpīṭhamadhye agniśikhākārā gaṇeśamūrttir varttate |tatpīṭhamadhye 'gniśikhākāraikā murtir vartate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. ll. 8 9): tasyā mūrter dhyānakaraṇāt sakalakāvyanāṭakādisakalavāṅmayaṃ vinābhyāsena puruṣasya manomadhye sphurati |tasyā mūrter dhyānakaraṇāt śāstrakāvyanāṭakādisakalavāṅmayaṃ vinābhyāsena puruṣasya manomadhye sphurati/ asya bahir ānandā// yogānandā// vīrānandā// uparamānandā// ajapājapaśat// 600// ghaṭi 9 palāni 40//

vīrānandā ] virānandā (U2)

The whole section is missing in englishD, englishN1, englishN2 and englishU1. Equally detailed passages for the other cakras which include assignments to various categories like daivata, bījas, etc., occur in englishU2 only. Subsequently, these passages were either lost in transmission in all other witnesses and were preserved in englishU2 only, or the extensive description of the first cakra occurred randomly, and the additions of englishU2 are not authorial. As these passages are of interest for the history and usage of the text, they have been added to the edition and are presented in another color to indicate their supplementary status.

[ 4. First Cakra] \smallskip

Now, the means for the genesis of knowledge in the central channel is described. At the beginning [of the central channel] exists the four petalled root cakra. The first cakra of support (ādhāra) is at the anus [and] is red colored. Gaṇeśa is the deity he is success, intelligence, and power. The mount is a rat. Kūrma is the seer. Contraction is the seal. Apāna is the vitalwind. Ūrmi is the digit. Ojasvinī is the concentration. In the four petals [exists] rajas, sattva, tamas and the mind faculties, [as well as] vaṃ śaṃ ṣaṃ and saṃ. A trident is situated in the middle of the triangle. In the middle is a trident, and kāmapīṭhaThis refers to one of the four pīṭhas of tantric Buddhism and the Kaula Yoginī Tantra named Kāmarūpa, specifically the present day Kāmākhyā Temple in Assam, which is located at different parts of the yogic body in various yoga traditions. For an in depth discussion of the term, see liersch2023, rosati2020 and asiddhi. The Śārṅgadharapaddhati, Śivayogapradīpikā and Siddhasiddhāntapaddhati place Kāmarūpa at the brahmacakra. in the shape of a triangle. In the middle of this seat (pīṭha) exists a single form in the shape of a flame. By meditating on this form, the whole literature, all śāstras, all poems, dramas, etc., everything [related to] elocution, appears in the person's mind without learning. [Assigned to it are] external bliss, yogic bliss, heroic bliss [and] the bliss of coming to restEarly accounts of "four blisses" can be found in descriptions of sexual yoga in some Vajrayāna works (cf. isaac2014 and sferra2000). The earliest mention of these blisses is in the hevajra (1.1.28 et passim), which identifies them as ānanda, paramānanda, sahajānanda, and viramānanda. The final bliss, viramānanda, is known as the "Bliss of Cessation" and refers to the feeling of pleasure experienced by the male partner during sexual ritual at the moment of ejaculation. The concept of the four blisses was later incorporated into the Amṛtasiddhi, the earliest text to outline many of the fundamental principles and practices of haṭhayoga. However, the Amṛtasiddhi contrasts the principles of sexual ritual with the celibate yoga method of male ascetics, which rejected sexual intercourse altogether. The text states that semen (bindu) is the source of "the Blisses whose last is Virama" (referring to the four blisses in Vajrayāna) in 7.4, and in 34.3, it asserts that the accomplished yogin delights in the three ānandas (likely ānanda, paramānanda, and sahajānanda) without the bliss of ejaculation, reflecting the celibate yoga taught (cf. asiddhi). In a complex process of adaptation, reconfiguration, and innovation, systems of four blisses were incorporated into texts of the late medieval period, such as the Yogatattvabindu. The Amaraughaprabodha, one of the earliest texts in the haṭhayoga corpus, and other later texts that quote the Amṛtasiddhi, modified or removed concepts unique to Buddhism, including technical terms from Vajrayāna sexual yoga ( birch2019). The Amanaska, the earliest text on Rājayoga, also mentions various blisses such as ānanda, paramānanda, sahajānanda, and cinmātrānanda throughout the text ( birch2013).. A hundredfold recitation of the non recited 600; 9 ghaṭis [and] 40 palās.Instructions for the duration of the practice of meditation are in most of the additions of U2 \ldots

[ 5. Second Cakra]

cf. SSP 2.2 (Ed. p. 28): dvitīyaṃ svādhiṣṭhānacakram | tanmadhye paścimābhimukhaṃ liṅgaṃ pravālāṅkurasadṛśaṃ dhyāyet | tatraivoḍyānapīṭhaṃ jagadākarṣaṇaṃ bhavati | \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 1r. ll. 9 11): liṃgo dvitīyaṃ ṣaṭdalaṃ svādhiṣṭānasaṃjñakaṃ kamalaṃ udyānapīṭhasaṃjñakaṃ vartate | tatra atiraktaṃ yahbhā saṃjñakaṃ tejaḥ | tasyā nāt sādhakaḥ atisuṃdarāṃgasan yuvatīnām ativallabhaḥ san pratidinam āyuṣyābhivṛddhimān bhavati | cha |cf. YSv (PT p. 832): liṅgamūle tu pīṭhābhaṃ (raktābhaṃ YK 1.253) svādhiṣṭhānan tu ṣaḍdalam | tanmadhye bālasūryābhaṃ mahajjyotiḥ susiddhidam | dhyānāc ca varddhate āyuḥ kandarpasamatāṃ vrajet |idānīṃ dvitīyaṃ svādhiṣṭhānacakraṃ ṣaṭdalaṃ uḍḍīyāṇapīṭhasaṃjñakaṃ bhavati/ liṅgaṃ sthānaṃ// pītaṃ varṇaṃ// pītā prabhā// rajo guṇaḥ// brahmā devatā// vaikharī vāk// sāvitrī śaktiḥ// haṃso vāhanaṃ// vahaṇo ṛṣiḥ// kāmāgnir prabhā// sthūlo dehaḥ// jāgrad avasthā// ṛg vedaḥ// ācāryaḥ liṅgaṃ// brahmasalokatā mokṣaḥ// śuddhabhumikā tattvaṃ// gaṃdho viṣayaḥ// apānaḥ vāyuḥ// aṃtar mātṛkā// vaṃ bhaṃ maṃ yaṃ raṃ laṃ// bahir mātrā// kāmā// kāmākhyā// tejasvinī// ceṣṭikā// alasā// mithunā// ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ// 6000 // gha. 16 pa. 40// tanmadhye 'tiraktavarṇaṃ tejo vartate/ tasya dhyānāt sā dhako 'tisundaro bhavati/ yuvatīnāṃ ativallabho bhavati/ pratidinam āyur vardhate//

This additional sentence occurs in englishN2 and the Yogasaṃgraha only.

[ 5. Second Cakra]

for each cakra, except the seventh cakra at the palate and the ninth cakra named mahāśūnyacakra. 600 ajapājapa refers to the duration of the voiceless uttering of the ``natural'' mantra of the breath: so 'haṃ (``he is I'') haṃ sa (``I am him''). The same duration of ajapājapas for meditation on cakras is also found in the Jogpradīpyakā of Jayatarāma in verses 889 912. As in many other yoga texts, the total amount of ajapājapa per day is declared to be 21600. If 21600 ajapājapa would equal 24 hours, then 600 ajapājapa would equal ≈ 40 minutes. In the additions of U2, one finds the same numbers of ajapājapa as in the instructions for meditation onto the seven cakra system of Jayatarāma (cf. jogpradipyaka). Ignoring this discrepancy, the scribe of U2 applied this system of seven cakras to nine cakras of Rāmacandra. The following instruction of ``ghaṭi 9 palāni 40'' is not entirely clear. Usually one ghaṭi equals 1/60 of a day (cf. sircar1966), which is 24 minutes. One pala equals 1/60 of a ghaṭi, which is 24 seconds (cf. petersburger4). This conception is explicitly stated in the earliest Rājayoga text, the Amanaska in 1.35 (cf. birch2013). For a more detailed tracing of the usage of the system in yogic and tantric literature, see birch2013. According to the system mentioned above, 9 ghaṭis and 40 palas would equal 232 minutes. Possibly ``ajapājapaśat || 600 || ghaṭi 9 palāni 40 ||'' must then be understood cumulatively, which would equal 272 minutes for the duration of meditation onto the first cakra. Other systems are less specific. kumbhaka 208, i.e. states that ``Six winkings are one prāṇa, six prāṇas make up one pala. Sixty palas equal the time period of a ghaṭikā.'' (ṣaṇṇimeṣo bhavat prāṇaḥ ṣaḍbhiḥ prāṇaiḥ palaṃ smṛtaṃ | palaiḥ ṣaṣṭibhir eva syād ghaṭikākālasammitā || 208 ||). Now, the second, the six petalled Svādhiṣṭānacakra known as the seat of UḍḍīyāṇaThe term uḍḍīyāṇa originally refers to one of the four pīṭhas of tantric Buddhism and the Kaula Yoginī Tantra, see white1996. According to urban2010 (2010) and kowski1988 (1988), \ldots [is described]. The gender (liṅga) is the location. The color is yellow. The shine is yellow. Rajas is the quality. Brahmā is the deity. Vaikharī is the speech. Sāvitrī is the power. The mount is the goose. Vahaṇa is the seer. Kāmāgni is the appearance. The body is gross. Being awake is the state. Ṛg is the Veda. The penis (liṅga) is the spiritual guide. Liberation is residing in the same world as the Brahman. The pure level (śuddhabhūmikā) is the principle. The sphere is the smell. Apāna is the vitalwind. The internal matrix [is]: vaṃ bhaṃ maṃ yaṃ raṃ laṃ. The external matrix [is]: Kāmā, Kāmākhyā, Tejasvinī, Ceṣṭikā, Alasā [and] Mithunā. A thousandfold recitation of the non recited; 6000; 16 ghaṭis [and] 40 palās. In its middle exists an extremely red glow. The adept becomes very handsome through meditation on it. He becomes one whom young women desire. The vital force increases from day to day.

[ 6. Third Cakra]

cf. YSv (PT p. 832): tṛtīyaṃ nābhideśe tu digdalaṃ paramādbhutam | mahāmeghaprabhaṃ tat tu koṭividyutsamanvitam | kalpāntāgnisamaṃ (kalpānto 'gni° YK 1.255) jyotis tanmadhye saṃsthitaṃ svayam | tasya (asya YK 1.256) dhyānāc cirāyuḥ syād arogo (arogī YK 1.256) jagatāṃ varaḥ (jagatāmvaraḥ YK 1.256) | sarvapāpavinirmukto jagatkṣobhakaro (jaganmokṣakaro YK 1.256) mahān |cf. tṛtīyaṃ (ceteri) ] tṛtīye (E), atha tṛtīyaṃ maṇipūracakraṃ (U2), tṛtīyacakraṃ (N2)

mūrter dhyā (ceteri) ] mūrtir (L), om. (U2)

sthiraṃ (ceteri) ] om. (P)
bhavati (ceteri) ] bhavati vā (U1), om. (P)

This sentence is omitted in englishL.

[ 6. Third Cakra]

Uḍḍiyāna is probably situated in the Swat valley in modern Pakistan. Throughout the text corpus of Haṭhayoga, the pīṭhas are repeatedly located differently in the yogic body. Additionally, the term refers to a certain yogic technique classified as mudrā, see rootsofyoga2017. Depending on the text and tradition, there are different models. The third, a ten petalled lotus, exists at the location of the navel. The color is red. Viṣṇu is the deity. Lakṣmī is the power. Vāyu is the seer. Samāna is the vitalwind. Garuḍa is the mount. The subtle body is the deityA second deity seems redundant here.. Sleep is the state. Madhyamāvāg is the speech. Yajur[veda] is the Veda. The southern fire is the fire. Samīpatā is the liberation. Viṣṇu is the guruliṅgaFor the phallus of Śiva, considered as one’s teacher or guide, cf. shivapura 1.18.31.. Water is the principle. Rajoviṣaya is the sphere. There are ten petals [and] ten matrices. [The] inner matrix: ḍaṃ ṭaṃ ṇaṃ taṃ thaṃ daṃ dhaṃ naṃ paṃ phaṃ. The external matrix: Śānti, Kṣamā, Medhā, Tanayā, Medhavinī, Puṣkarā, Haṃsagamanā, Lakṣyā, Tanmayā and Amṛtā. A thousandfold recitation of the non recited; 6000; 16 ghaṭis [and] 40 palās.The additions of U2 for each cakra are discussed on p. . In its middle exists a cakra with five angles. In the middle of it is a single [divine] form. It is not possible to describe her shine with speech. Through the execution of meditation on this [divine] form, the body of the person becomes strong.

[ 7. Fourth Cakra]

cf. YSv (PT p. 832): anāhatam aṣṭapīṭhaṃ (mahāpīṭhaṃ YK 1.257) caturthakamalaṃ hṛdi | sūryapatraṃ mahājyotir mahāsūkṣman tu cākṣuṣam | sūryapatraṃ dvādaśadalam (sentence om.in YK) | tanmadhye 'ṣṭadalaṃ padmam ūrddhavaktraṃ mahāprabham | \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 2): hṛdayamadhye dvadaśadalaṃcf. SSP 2.4 (Ed. p. 30): caturthaṃ hṛdayacakram aṣṭadalakamalam adhomukhaṃ tanmadhye karṇikāyāṃ liṅgākārāṃ jyotīrūpām dhyāyet | saiva haṃsakalā sarvendriyavaśyā bhavati |caturthaṃ hṛdayamadhye dvādaśadalaṃ kamalaṃ vartate/ anāhatacakraṃ hṛdayasthānaṃ// śvetaṃ varṇaṃ// tamo guṇaḥ// rudro devatā// umā śaktiḥ// hiraṇyagarbha ṛṣiḥ// nandi vāhanaṃ// prāṇo vāyuḥ// jyotiskalākāraṇaṃ deham// suṣuptir avasthā// paśyantī vācā// sāmavedaḥ// gārhapatyo 'gniḥ// śivo liṅgaṃ// prāptiḥ bhūmikā// sarūpatā muktiḥ// dvādaśādalāni// dvādaśamātrā// kaṃ khaṃ gaṃ ghaṃ ṇaṃ caṃ chaṃ jaṃ jhaṃ yaṃ taṃ thaṃ// bahir mātrā// rudrāṇī// tejasā// tāpinī// sukhadā// caitanyā// śivadā// śāntiḥ// umā// gaurī// mātarā// jvālā// pra:jvālinī// ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ// 6000// gha. 96 pa. 40// \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 2): tejomayatvāt | dṛṣṭigocaraṃ na bhavaty etādṛśaṃ vartateatitejomayatvād dṛṣṭigocaraṃ na bhavati/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 3): tanmadhye 'ṣṭadalaṃ adhomukhaṃ kamalaṃ ||tanmadhye 'ṣṭadalam am adhomukhaṃ kamalaṃ vartate/ manaś cakre// mano devatā// bahiśśaktiḥ// ātmā ṛṣiḥ// nābhimadhye sthitaṃ padmaṃ nālaṃ tasya daśāṅgulaṃ/ komalaṃ tasya tan nālaṃ nirmalaṃ cāpy adhomukhaṃ/ kadalīpuṣpasaṃkāśaṃ tan:madhye ca pratiṣṭhitaṃ/ mana ānaty asaṃkalpam/ vikalpātmakam eva ca/ pūrvadale śvetavarṇe yadā viśramate manaḥ// dharmakīrtividyādisadbuddhir bhavati/ agnikoṇe āraktavarṇe nidrālasyamāyāmandamatir bhavati/ dakṣiṇe kṛṣṇavarṇeti tadā krodhotpattir bhavati/ nairṛtye nīlavarṇe mamatāmatir bhavati/ paścime kapilavarṇe krīḍāhāsotsavotsāhamatir:bhavati/ vāyavye śyāmavarṇe cintodvegamatir bhavati/ uttare pītavarṇe bhogaśṛṅgāramahodayamatir bhavati/ īśāne gauravarṇe jñānasaṃdhānamatir bhavati/

caturthaṃ (ceteri) ] caturthacakrakamalaṃ (N2)
kamalaṃ (ceteri) ] om. (N2)
vartate (ceteri) ] asti (U2), bhavati (N2)

gocaraṃ (ceteri) ] gocaratāṃ (U2)
bhavati (ceteri) ] yāti (U2)
'ṣṭadalam a (E U2) ] 'ṣṭadale (P), ṣṭadalaṃ (L), aṣṭadalaṃ (X)
m adhomukhaṃ kamalaṃ (ceteri) ] adhomukhakamalaṃ (L), mukhaṃ kamalaṃ (P)
vartate (ceteri) ] asti (U2)
bahiśśaktiḥ ] bahiśaktiḥ (U2)
ātmā ] ātma° (U2)
daśāṅgulaṃ ] daśāgulaṃ (U2)
ānaty a ] unnaty (U2)
saṃkalpam ] asaṃkalpa (U2)
śveta ] sveta° (U2)
viśramate ] viśrāmate (U2)
nidrālasya ] nidrā ālasya° (U2)
nairṛtye ] naiṛtye (U2)
śyāma ] śāma (U2)
jñānasaṃdhāna ] jñānasaṃdhāne (U2)

The conjecture is based on the the usage in kriyakrama (Ed. p. 96). It can also be found in sakalagama quoted with reference siddhāntaśekhare (Ed. p. 80). Both texts use the term in the context of cakras, channels, breath retention and visualization.

[ 7. Fourth Cakra]

The fourth twelve petalled lotus exists in the middle of the heart. The place of the Anāhatacakra is within the heart. The color is white. Tamas is the quality. Rudra is the deity. Umā is the power. Hiraṇyagarbha is the Ṛṣi. Nandi is the mount. Prāṇa is the vitalwind. The instrument of the digit of light is the body. Deep sleep is the state. Paśyantī is the speech. Sāma[veda] is the Veda. The fire is the fire of the householder. Śiva is the liṅga. The power to attain anything (prāpti) is the level. Sarūpatā is the liberation. [There are] twelve petals, [and] twelve matrices: kaṃ khaṃ gaṃ ghaṃ ṇaṃ caṃ chaṃ jaṃ jhaṃ yaṃ taṃ [and] thaṃ. The external matrix: Rudrāṇī, Tejasā, Tāpinī, Sukhadā, Caitanyā, Śivadā, Śānti, Umā, Gaurī, Mātarā, Jvalā [and] Prajvālinī. A thousandfold recitation of the non recited; 6000; 16 ghaṭis [and] 40 palās. Due to being made of [such an] intense light, [the fourth lotus] is not in the range of sight. In its middle exists an eight petalled lotus facing downwards. \indent The mind resides in the cakra. Manas is the deity. Bahi is the power.The term bahiśśaktiḥ designates the visualization of the external energy infused by inhalation that permeates the body. sakalagama quoted with reference siddhāntaśekhare (Ed. p. 80): caraṇāṅguṣṭhayoryugmāt sañcintya suṣirāntanau | suṣirāntabahiśśaktiṃ vyāpinīṃ cintayet tataḥ || The Ṛṣi is the self. In the middle of the navel exists a lotus. Its stalk measures ten aṅgulas. The stalk is soft, pure [and] facing downwards. In its middle [it is] endowed with the shine of a banana flower. The mind is unstable, fickle, and full of doubt. While the mind rests on the white eastern petal, clear intellect [endowed with] dharma, fame and knowledge, etc., arises. While in the southeast, [which is] reddish, a weak mind arises due to sleep, laziness, and illusion. While in the right south, [being] black, anger is generated. While in the southwest, [being] blue in color, a mind of pride arises. While in the West, [being] brown, a mind that is longing for play, laughing, and celebration arises. While in the northwest, [being] dark in color, a mind restless by sorrow arises. While in the north, [being] yellow, a delighted mind with erotic and enjoyment arises. While in the northeast [being] whitish, a mind of unity through knowledge arises. \fill

= Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 3 4): ta ca prāṇavāyoḥ sthānam | aṣṭadalakamalamadhye liṃgākārā karṇikācf. YSv (PT p. 832): prāṇavāyoḥ sthalañcāsya liṅgākāran tu karṇikā | kālikākhyā karṇikeyaṃ asyā madhye tu kuṇḍalī |tanmadhye prāṇavāyoḥ sthānam aṣṭadalakamalamadhye liṃgākārā karṇikā kathyate/ = Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 4): kaliketi saṃjñikāsti tanmadhye padmarāgaratnasamānavarṇā aṃguṣṭhapramāṇā ekā puttalikācf. YSv (PT p. 832): padmavatyāḥ (padmāvatyāḥ YK 1.259) prabhāṅguṣṭhapramāṇā (°prāmāṇa° YK 1.259) ratnasannibhā | tasyā saṅgī (tasya saṅgī YK 1.260) jīva iti ananto balarūpataḥ | asya dhyānaṃ (dhyānād YK 1.260) jagadvaśyaṃ khecarīsarvago bhavet | bhavanti vaśyā devādyāś cintākarttur na (citta° YK 1.260) cānyathā | iṣṭāniṣṭo (iṣṭāniṣṭa YK 1.261) bhaved vaśyaḥ (vaśyaṃ YK 1.261) satyaṃ satyaṃ na saṃśayaḥ | iṣṭasiddhir bhavet tasya sarvajñādiguṇodayaḥ |tasyāḥ kaliketi saṃjñā/ tatka:likāmadhye padmarāgaratnasamānavarṇāṅguṣṭhapramāṇaikā puttalikā vartate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 5): jīveti saṃjñikāsti | tasyāḥ balaṃ svarūpaṃ ca koṭijihvābhir vaktuṃ na śakyaṃ ||tasyā jīveti saṃjñā/ tasyā balaṃ atha ca svarūpaṃ koṭijihvābhir var vaktuṃ na śakyate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 5 6): asyā mūrtter dhyānakaraṇāt sādhakasya svargapātāla ākāśagaṃdharvakiṃnaraguhyakavidyādharastrīyo vaśā bhavati |asyā mūrter dhyānakāraṇāt svargapātālākaśamanuṣyagandharvakinnaraguhyaka:vidyādharalokasaṃbandhinyaḥ strīyaḥ sādhakasya puruṣasya vaśyā bhavanti/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 6 7): pṛthvī loke manuṣyādi striṇāṃ kākathā cha |ity atra kiṃ kathyate//

vāyoḥ (ceteri) ] °vāyo (U1 U2)
karṇikā (ceteri) ] karṇi (U2)
kaliketi (ceteri) ] kalikeli (L), karṇiketi (E)
saṃjñā (ceteri) ] om. (L)
tatka:likāmadhye (ceteri) ] tataḥ (N2), om. (L)
rāgaratnasamānavarṇāṅguṣṭhapramāṇaikā ] °rāgasamānavarṇāṃguṣṭhapramāṇaikā (E), °ratnasamānavarṇā aṃguṣṭhapramāṇā ekā (L), °rāgaratnasamānavarṇāṃ || aṃguṣṭhapramāṇā || ekā (P N1), °rāgaratnasamānavarṇa aṃguṣṭhapramāṇā ekā (N2), °rāgaratnasamānavarṇā aṃguṣṭhapramāṇāt ekā (D U1)
tasyā (E P) ] tasyāḥ (X), tasya (L U2)
jīveti saṃjñā (U2) ] jīveti saṃjñāḥ (N1), jīveti saṃjñaḥ || (N2), jīveti saṃjña | (D), jīvasaṃjñā || (Y), om. (L)
tasyā (E N2 P) ] tasyāḥ (D N1 U1), tasya (U2)
balaṃ atha ca svarūpaṃ (ceteri) ] balamadhyasvarūpaṃ (E), bala sappa svarūpaṃ (L), balam atha svarūpaṃ (P), balaṃ tasya atha svarūpaṃ (U2)
koṭijihvābhir va (ceteri) ] koṭijihvāyābhi (L)

\vfill \nolinenumbers \smallskip [ 8. Fifth Cakra] \linenumbers

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 7): kaṃṭhasthāne paṃcamaṃ ṣodaśadalaṃ viśudhhasaṃjñakaṃ cakraṃ varttate ||cf. YSv (PT p. 832) = YK 1.262: kalāpatraṃ pañcaman tu viśuddhaṃ kaṇṭhadeśataḥ |idānīṃ pañcamaṃ kamalaṃ ṣodaśadalaṃ kaṇṭhasthāne vartate/ dhūmraṃ varṇaṃ// jīvo devatā// avidyā śaktiḥ// virāṭ ṛṣiḥ// vāyur vāhanaṃ// udāno vāyuḥ// jvālā kalā// jālaṃdharo bandhaḥ// mahākāraṇaḥ dehaḥ// tūrya āvasthā//

idānīṃ (X) ] om. (Y)
kamalaṃ ṣodaśadalaṃ kaṇṭhasthāne (N1 D U1) ] kamalaṣodaśadalaṃ kaṇṭhasthāne (N2), kaṇṭhasthāne ṣoḍaśadalaṃ kamalaṃ (E P L), viśuddhacakraṃ kaṃṭhastāne (U2)
dhūmraṃ varṇaṃ ] dhūmravarṇe (U2)
virāṭ ṛ ] virāṭha (U2)
udāno ] udāna° (U2)
mahākāraṇaḥ dehaḥ ] mahākāraṇadeha (U2)
tūrya āvasthā ] tūryāvasthā (U2)

It is said that in its middle is the place of the prāṇa vital wind [and] in the middle [of] the eight petalled lotus is a pericarp (karṇikā) in the form of a liṅga. The technical designation of her is bud (kalikā).A similar concept, including the usage of the term kalikā, is found in the chapter on creation (sargakāṇḍa) of the ramatosana. In a quotation attributed to a text called Śāktānanda, the jīva is described as having the shape of a bud of light (pradīpakalikākāro jīvo) and always resides in the heart: ādau sañjāyate bījaṃ brahmāṇḍaṃ sahasāṅkuraḥ | tasya madhye sumeruś ca kaṅkāladaṇḍarūpadhṛk | carācarāṇāṃ sarveṣāṃ devādīnāṃ viśeṣataḥ | ālayaḥ savabhūtānāṃ meror abhyantare 'pi ca | pradīpakalikākāro jīvo hṛdi sadā sthitaḥ | In the middle of this bud exists a single thumb sized [divine] figurine (puttalikā)The concept of a puttalikā in the heart can be traced back to the Kaula Tantras, e.g., the saradaavalon 22.126 128: puttalikāyā hṛdayaṃ spṛśan prāṇā iha prāṇā jīva iha sthita iti indriyāṇi spṛśan sarvendriyāṇi vāṅmanaścakṣuḥśrotraghrāṇeti sarvāṅgaṃ spṛśan prāṇā ihāyāntu sukhaṃ ciraṃ tiṣṭhan tu iti śiraḥ spṛśan svāheti japet | mantranyāsam iti | being similar to a ruby gem in color. Her technical designation is embodied soul (jīva).The idea of the thumb sized soul residing in the heart is already present in the oldest strata of yogic literature. See kathaup 6.17: aṅguṣṭhamātraḥ puruṣo 'ntarātmā sadā janānāṃ hṛdaye saṃniviṣṭaḥ | taṃ svāc charīrāt pravṛhen muñjād iveṣīkāṃ dhairyeṇa | taṃ vidyāc chukram amṛtaṃ taṃ vidyāc chukram amṛtam iti ||17|| Also cf. hauschild1927 3.13. Not even with a thousand tongues is it possible to talk about her nature and her power. Here it is said [that]: ``Because of the exercise of meditation on this form the inhabitants of the universe [which are] Humans, Gandharvas, Kinnaras, Guhyakas, Vidyādharas, and [their] females, in the heavenly world, underworld, and open space are obedient to the will of the practicing person.''\vfill \vfill [ 8. Fifth Cakra] \indent Now, the fifth sixteen petalled lotus exists at the throat's location. The color is grey. The embodied soul (jīva) is the deity. Ignorance is the power. Virāṭ is the Ṛṣi. The wind (vāyu) is the mount. Udāna is the vitalwind. The flame is the digit (kalā). Jālandhara is the binding (bandha). The primordial cause (mahākāraṇa) is the body. The fourth state (tūrya) is the state.

cf. SSP 2.5 (Ed. pp. 30 31): pañcamaṃ kaṇṭhacakraṃ caturaṅgulam | tatra vāma iḍā candranāḍī | dakṣiṇe piṅgalā sūryanāḍī | tanmadhye suṣumnāṃ dhyāyet | saiva anāhatakalā anāhatasiddhidā bhavati |parā vācā// atharvaṇo vedaḥ// jaṅgamaṃ liṅgaṃ// jīvaprāptā bhūmikā// sāyujyatā mokṣaḥ// ṣoḍaśadalāni// ṣoḍaśamātrāḥ// antarmātrā// aṃ āṃ iṃ īṃ u ūṃ ṛṃ ṝṃ ḷṃ ḹṃ eṃ aiṃ oṃ auṃ aṃ aṃḥ// bahir mātrā// vidyā// avidyā// icchā// śaktiḥ// jñānaśaktiḥ// śatalā// mahāvidyā// mahāmāyā// buddhiḥ// tāmasī// maitrā// kumārī// maitrāyaṇī// rudrā// puṣṭā// siṃhanī// ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ// 1000// gha. 2 pa. 46 akṣara 40// \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 7 8): tatra koṭicaṃdraprabha ekaḥ puruṣo stitanmadhye koṭicandrasamaprabhaḥ ekaḥ puruṣo vartate/ cf. YSv (PT p. 832) = YK 1.262: asya madhye pumān ekaḥ koṭicandrasamaprabhaḥ | naśyantya sādhyarogā hi sahasrāyuś ca cintanāt |= Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. l. 8): tasya puruṣasya dhyānakaraṇād asādhyarogā naśyaṃti ||tasya puruṣasya dhyānakaraṇād asādhyarogā naśyanti/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. l. 8): sahasravarṣaṃ jīvati |ekasahasravarṣaparyantaṃ puruṣo jīvati//\vfill

atharvaṇo ] atharvaṇa (U2)
jaṅgamaṃ ] jaṃgama° (U2)
antarmātrā ] antarmātrār carāḥ (U2)
icchā ] ichā (U2)
śaktiḥ ] śakti (U2)
tāmasī ] tamasī (U2)
puṣṭā ] puṣṭa° (U2)
ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ ] ajapājapasahasra (U2)
samaprabhaḥ (ceteri) ] °samaprabhaḥ || (U2), °samaprabhā (L D), °sūryasamāna (E)
ekaḥ puruṣo (ceteri) ] ekapuruṣo (D), eka pumān (U2)
puruṣasya (ceteri) ] puṃsaḥ (U2)

puruṣo (ceteri) ] sa puruṣo (E P)
jīvati (ceteri) ] jīvati |cha| (U1), jīvatīdānīṃ (E)
\nolinenumbers \smallskip [ 9. Sixth Cakra] \linenumbers

cf. YSv (PT p. 832): ājñākhyaṃ ṣaṣṭhakaṃ (ṣaṭkaṃ YK 1.264) cakraṃ bhruvor madhye dvipatrakam | agnijvālānibhaṃ jyotiḥ puṃsaḥ strīto (pūṃsastrīto YK 1.264) vivarjitam | dhyānāc cāsya sarvasiddhirajarāmaratāṃ vrajet |Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 8 9): bhrūvor madhye dvidalaṃ ājñācakraṃ ṣaṣṭhaṃ |cf. SSP 2.7 (Ed. p. 31): saptamaṃ bhrūcakraṃ madhyamāṅguṣṭhamatram | tatra jñānanetraṃ dīpaśikhākāraṃ dhyāyet | tatra vāksiddhir bhavati |idānīṃ ṣaṣṭhacakraṃ ājñānāmakaṃ vartate/ agnir devatā// suṣumṇā śaktiḥ// hiṃso ṛṣiḥ// caitanyaṃ vāhanaṃ// jñāno dehaḥ// vijñānāvasthā// anupamā vācā// sāmavedaḥ// pramādaḥ liṃgaṃ// ardhā mātrā// ākāśaṃtattvaṃ// jīvo haṃsaḥ// caitanyalīlā āraṃbhaḥ// dve mātrā// haṃ kṣaṃ// aṃtar mātrā// bahir mātrā// sthitiḥ// prabhā// ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ// 1000// gha. 2 pa. 46 akṣara 40// \fill

ṣaṣṭhacakraṃ (X) ] ṣaṣṭhaṃ bhrūmadhye (E P), ṣaṣṭhaḥ bhrūmadhye (L), ṣaṣṭa bhrūmadhye (U2)
ājñā (ceteri) ] ajñā (N1 N2 D)
nāmakaṃ (U1 D N1) ] nāmaka (N2), cakraṃ (E P L), cakraṃ raktavarṇaṃ (U2)
vartate (ceteri) ] om. (U2)
agnir de ] āgnir (U2)
hiṃso ] hiṃsa° (U2)
caitanyaṃ ] caitanya° (U2)
jñāno dehaḥ ] jñānadehī (U2)
anupamā ] anupama° (U2)
pramādaḥ ] pramāda° (U2)
ardhā mātrā ] ardhamātrā (U2)
ākāśaṃ ] ākāśā (U2)
jīvo haṃsaḥ ] jīvahiṃsa (U2)
līlā āraṃbhaḥ ] °līlāraṃbhaḥ (U2)
sthitiḥ ] sthiti (U2)
ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ ] ajapājapasahasra (U2)

Parā is the speech. Atharvaṇa[veda] is the Veda. The movable is the characteristic (liṅga). Jīvaprāptā is the earth. The liberation is the union with the deity (sāyujyatā). [Associated with it are] sixteen petals [and] sixteen matrices. The internal matrix: aṃ āṃ iṃ īṃ u ūṃ ṛṃ ṝṃ ḷṃ ḹṃ eṃ aiṃ oṃ auṃ aṃ aṃḥ. The external matrix: Vidyā, Avidyā, Icchā, Śakti, Jñānaśakti, Śatalā, Mahāvidyā, Mahāmayā, Buddhi, Tāmasī, Maitrā, Kumārī, Maitrāyaṇī, Rudrā, Puṣṭā, Siṃhanī. A thousandfold recitation of the non recited; 1000; 2 ghaṭis, 46 palās. 40 akṣarasAccording to birch2013 (2013) the time unit akṣara appears in Bhāskara's siddharoma (17cd − 18ab of the Kālamānādhyāya in the Madhyamādhikāra): gurvakṣaraiḥ khendumitair asus taiḥ | ṣaḍbhiḥ palaṃ tair ghaṭikā khaṣaḍbhiḥ || syād vā ghaṭīṣaṣṭir ahaḥ kharāmair māso dinaistair dvikubhiś ca varṣam | Translation by birch2013: A breath is ten long syllables, and a Pala is six breaths, sixty Palas is one Ghaṭikā, sixty Ghaṭikās is a day, thirty days is a month, and twelve months is a year. If one assumes an akṣara to be 1/10 of a breath and 21600 breaths per day, one hour would have 900 breaths, one minute would equal 16 breaths, one breath would equal 4 seconds, and one akṣara would be 0,4 seconds or 400 milliseconds. Thus, the ten akṣaras given here would equal 16 seconds.. In its middle exists a single person shining like a thousand moons. Because of the exercise of meditation on this person, all diseases which are [otherwise] not possible to be controlled vanish. The person lives up to 1001 years.

[ 9. Sixth Cakra] Now, a sixth cakra named Ājñā exists. Agni is the deity. The central channel (suṣumṇā) is the power. Hiṃsa is the Ṛṣi. Consciousness (caitanya) is the mount. Knowledge (vijñāna) is the body. Understanding is the stage. The incomparable (anupama) is the speech. Sāma[veda] is the Veda. Intoxication (pramāda) is the characteristic (liṅgaṃ). The half matrix: the principle of ether. Jīva is the gander, and the play of consciousness the origin, [represent the] twofold matrix. The inner matrix: haṃ kṣam. The external matrix: Sthiti [and] Prabhā. A thousandfold recitation of the non recited; 1000; 2 ghaṭis, 46 palās, and 40 akṣaras. \fill

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. l. 9): gnijvālākāraṃ paramātmasaṃjñakaṃ vastv āsti |tac cakraṃ bhruvor madhye dvidalakaṃ sthitaṃ tanmadhye 'gnijvālākāram akalaṃ kiṃcid vastu vartate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. ll. 9 10): tac ca na strīpumān | tasya dhyānakaraṇād ajarāmaraḥ sādhako bhavati |cha|na strī na pumān/ tasya dhyānakaraṇāt puruṣasya śarīram ajarāmaraṃ bhavati// \vfill

tac cakraṃ bhruvor madhye dvidalakaṃ sthitaṃ (X) ] dvidalaṃ (E P L), om. (U2)
'gnijvālā (E) ] agnijvālā° (ceteri)
kāram akalaṃ ] °kāraṃ akalaṃ (D N1 N2), °kārakamalaṃ (Y), °kāraṃ akala (U1)
kiṃcid vastu (ceteri) ] kiṃcit vastu (U1)
na strī na pumān (ceteri) ] na strī pumān (E B L)
karaṇāt pu (ceteri) ] °karaṇāt | (U2)
śarīram ajarāmaraṃ (U2) ] śarīraṃ ajarāmaraṃ (D E N1 N2 U1), śarīraṃ ajarāmaro (B L P)
bhavati (ceteri) ] bhavati vā (U2)

Witness B starts here.

\nolinenumbers [ 10. Seventh Cakra] \linenumbers

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. l. 10): tālumadhye catuḥṣaṣṭhidalaṃ amṛtapūrṇaṃcf. YSv (PT pp. 832 833): catuḥṣaṣṭidalaṃ tālumadhye cakran tu madhyamam | pīyūṣapūrṇaṃ (pīyūṣapūrṇa° YK 1.266) koṭīndusannibhaṃ (°sannibha° YK 1.266) cāmṛtasthalī | tanmadhye ghaṭikāsaṃjñā karṇikā raktasannibhā | saha cendukalā tatrāmṛtadhārāṃ (tāndrā° YK 1.267) sravaty asau | etad dhyātvāmṛtaiḥ snātvā sadā yogāt pramucyate |idānīṃ saptamaṃ cakraṃ catuḥṣaṣṭhidalaṃ tālumadhye 'mṛtapūrṇaṃ vartate/ lalāṭaṃ maṇḍalaṃ// caṃdro devatā// amṛtā śaktiḥ// paramātmā ṛṣiḥ// amṛtavāsinī kalāsaptadaśī// amṛtakallolanadī mahākāśā// aṃbikā laṃbikā// ghaṃṭikā tālikā// ajapāgāyatrī dehasvarūpaṃ// kākamukhī// naranetrā// gośṛṃgā// lalāṭabrahma:paṭhā// hayagrīvā// mayūramukhā// haṃsavad aṃgāni// ajapāgāyatrī svarūpaṃ// \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. l. 11): adhikataraśobhayuktaṃ atiśvetaṃ cakraṃ | tanmadhye raktavarṇaghaṃṭikāsaṃjñā varttate |adhikataraśobhayuktaṃ// atiśvetaṃ// tanmadhye raktavarṇaṃ ghaṇṭikāsaṃjñā/ ekā karṇikā vartate/ tanmadhye bhūmiḥ/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2v. l. 11 2r. l.1): tanmadhye prakaṭacandrakalā amṛtādhārāsravaṃtī varttate |tanmadhye 'prakaṭacandrakalā amṛ:tadhārāsravantī vartate/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. l. 1): tasyāḥ kalāyā nirantaraṃ dhyānakartum maraṇaṃtasyāḥ kalāyā dhyānakaraṇāt tasya samīpe maraṇaṃ nāyāti/ nirantaradhyānakaraṇā:d amṛtadhārā sravati/\vfill

cakraṃ catuḥṣaṣṭhidalaṃ tālumadhye (X) ] tālumadhye catuḥṣaṣṭidalaṃ (E P U2), tāludeśe madhye catuḥṣaṣṭhidala (L B)
'mṛtapūrṇaṃ ] amṛtapūrṇaṃ (ceteri), amṛtapūrṇa (N2)
lalāṭaṃ ] lalāṭa° (U2)

atiśvetaṃ (ceteri) ] ||atiśvetaṃ|| (L B U2)
raktavarṇaṃ (ceteri) ] raktavarṇa° (N2)
ghaṇṭikā (ceteri) ] ghāṃṭikā° (E), ghaṭikā° (P), ghaṇikā° (L)
ekā (ceteri) ] ekā ekā (L B)
bhūmiḥ (ceteri) ] bhūmis° (U1), bhūmi (U2)
'prakaṭa (ceteri) ] pragaṭa (U1), °ṃdrakaṭaṃ (U2)
amṛ:tadhārāsravantī (ceteri) ] 'mṛtādhārā sravaṃti (L B), 'mṛtādhārā sravati (P U2), 'mṛtādhārā bhavati (E)
vartate (X) ] om. (Y)
kalāyā (ceteri) ] kalāyāḥ (N1 N2 U1), karṇikāyā (L B)
nāyāti (ceteri) ] na yāti (L B U2)
dhyānakaraṇā: (ceteri) ] °dhyānād (E P)
d amṛtadhārā (ceteri) ] amṛtadhārāyāḥ sajīvo (E), amṛtadhārā plāvanaṃ (P), amṛtadhārā plavanaṃ (U2)
sravati (L B U1) ] sravaṃti (N1 N2 D), bhavati (E P U2)

This cakra is located in the middle of the eyebrows and is two petalled. In its middle exists a certain object being a form of a blazing fire without parts, not being female, not being male. Because of the exercise of meditation on it, the body of the person becomes non aging and immortal.

[ 10. Seventh Cakra] Now, the seventh cakra, having sixty four petals and being full of nectar, exists in the middle of the palate. The forehead is the Maṇḍala. The moon is the deity. The nectar of immortality is the power. The supreme self is the Rṣi. The seventeenth digit is the resident with the nectar of immortality. The wavy stream of nectar the great space. The uvula is the mother. The ornament/rhythm? (tālikā) is a small bell. The own form of the body is the unspeakable Gāyatrī, [which has] the face of a crow, the eye of a human, the horn of a cow, a forehead that is Brahmapaṭhā?, a neck like a horse, the face of a peacock [and] limbs like a goose. [This is] the specific nature of the unspeakable Gayatrī. It is endowed with superabundant beauty. [It is] very bright, in its middle is that which is known as uvula (ghāṃṭikā)A similar concept of a cakra at the uvula can already be identified in kubji1988 7.85: lalanāghaṇṭike yojya pañcamaṃ sthānam ākramet | ākramed guhyacakraṃ tu karaṇaṃ cordhvamūlakam || being red in colour. [It] exists as a single pericarp. In its middle is a site. In the middle of it exists the hidden digit of the moon, being a stream of nectar like a river (amṛtādhārāsravantī). Because of the exercise of meditation on this digit, death does not reach him. Due to uninterrupted meditation, the stream (dhārā) of nectar flows. \fill

cf. YSv (PT p. 833): unmādajvarapittādidāhaśūlādivedanāḥ (°śūnyā° YK 1.268) | naśyanti ca śiroduḥkhaṃ jāḍyabhāvo 'pi naśyati | sadyodhyānādbhuktaviśvaṃ jihvājāḍyañ ca naśyati (last sentence om.in YK) \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. ll. 1 2): kṣayarogaḥ pettajvarahṛdayadāhaśiro..jihvāyājaḍyaṃ ca naśyati |tadā kṣayarogapittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvājaḍyabhāvā naśyanti/ bhakṣitaṃ viṣam api na bādhate/ yadyatra manaḥ sthiraṃ bhavati// \vfill

tadā (Y) ] om. (X)
kṣayarogapittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvājaḍyabhāvā ] yakṣamarogapittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvājaḍabhāvā (E), kṣayarogapittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvājaḍabhāvān (P), kṣayarogapittajvarahṛdayadāharogajihvāyājaḍabhāvān (L), kṣayarogapittajvarahṛdayadāharogajihvāyājaḍavān (B), kṣayarogaṃ pittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvāyājaḍabhāvā (N1), kṣayarogaṃ pittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvāyājaḍabhāvātā (N2), kṣayaṃ rogaṃ pittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvāyājaḍabhāvā (D), kṣayarogapittajvarahṛdayadāhaśirorogajihvāyājaḍabhāvā (U1), kṣayarogoptatti || jvara hṛdayadāha || śiroroga || jihvājaḍatā || dayo (U2)
bhakṣitaṃ (N2 U1) ] bhakṣitam (N1), bhakṣitāṃ (D), bhakṣitam api (E P L U2), bhākṣitamār pi (B)
viṣam api (X) ] viṣaṃ (L B U2), viṣan (E), viṃṣa (P)
bādhate (E P N2) ] bādhyate (ceteri)
yadyatra (ceteri) ] yady atram api (L B), yady anna (D N1)
manaḥ sthiraṃ (E P) ] manasthiraṃ (ceteri)
\nolinenumbers \smallskip [ 11. Eighth Cakra] \linenumbers

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. ll. 2 3): brahmaraṃdhre śatadalaṃ jālaṃdharapīṭhasaṃjñakaṃ siddhapuruṣasyānacakraṃcf. YSv (PT p. 833): brahmarandhre 'ṣṭamaṃ cakraṃ śatapatraṃ mahāprabham | jālandharaṃ nāma pīṭhaṃ etat tu parikīrttitam | siddhapuṃsaḥ (°puṃsa° YK 1.270) sthalaṃ jñātvā agnidhūmanibhā śikhā | ādimadhyāntahīnā strīpuṃmūrtti (°mūrtir YK 1.270) varttate parā | antajñānī (antaryāmī YK 1.271) bhaved dhyānād ākāśe 'pi samāgamaḥ | nirantaraṃ sarvavettā ity ūccāno mahān bhavet | jaganmadhye sthito jantur jagadbādhāvivarjitaḥ |cf. SSP 2.8 (Ed. pp. 31 32): aṣṭamaṃ brahmarandhraṃ nirvāṇacakraṃ sūcikāgrabhedyam | tatra dhūmaśikhākāraṃ dhyāyet | tatra jālandharapīṭhaṃ mokṣapradaṃ bhavati |idānīṃ aṣṭamacakraṃ brahmaraṃdhrasthāne śatadalaṃ vartate/ gurur devatā// caitanyaḥ śaktiḥ// virāṭ ṛṣiḥ sarvotkṛṣṭa:sākṣiḥ// bhūtaturyātītaṃ caitanyātmakaṃ// sarvavarṇāḥ// sarvamātrāḥ// sarvadalāni// virāṭ dehaḥ sthitāvasthā// prajñā vācā// sohaṃ vedaḥ// anupamaṃ sthānaṃ// ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ// 1000 ghaṭi 2 palā 46 akṣara 40// sarvajapaḥ saṃkhyā// 21600// ekaviṃśatisahasrāṇiṣaṭśatāni// tathaiva ca niśāhe vahate// prāṇaḥ yo jānāti sa paṃḍitaḥ// sakāreṇa bahir yāti hakāreṇa viśet punaḥ// haṃsaḥ sohaṃ// tato mantraṃ jīvo japati sarvadā// tasya kamalasya jālandharapīṭha iti saṃjñā/ siddhapuruṣasya sthānaṃ/

aṣṭamacakraṃ brahmaraṃdhrasthāne śatadalaṃ (D N1 N2) ] cakraṃ brahmaraṃdhrasthāne śatadalaṃ (U1), brahmarandhrasthāne 'ṣṭamaṃ śatadalaṃ cakraṃ (E P U2), brahmaraṃdhrasthāne aṣṭamaṃ śatadalaṃ cakraṃ (B L)
gurur de ] guru° (U2)
caitanyaḥ ] caitanya° (U2)
bhūtaturyātītaṃ ] bhūtaturyātīta° (U2)
dehaḥ ] deha° (U2)
vedaḥ ] veda (U2)
anupamaṃ ] anupama° (U2)
ajapājapaḥ sahasraḥ ] ajapājapasahasra (U2)
sarvajapaḥ ] sarvajapa° (U2)
kamalasya (ceteri) ] kamala° (E)
jālandharapīṭha (ceteri) ] jālandharapīṭha° (B), jātyadharaṇīpīṭha (E)
iti (ceteri) ] om. (B)
saṃjñā (ceteri) ] °saṃjñā (B)
puruṣasya sthānaṃ (ceteri) ] sthānam mūrti vartate (L B)

Then the appearances of emaciation (kṣayaroga)A fever which causes depletion in the body, cf. ayurveda, ayurveda., bilious fever (pittajvara)A fever due to disordered bile, cf. ibid. ayurveda., heartburn (hṛdayadāha)The burning sensation in the heart caused by heart disease resulting from disordered bile, cf. ibid. ayurveda., head disease (śiroroga) The term refers to disorders of the head. When blood, fat, phlegm, or vata decreases, it causes severe pain, cf. ibid. ayurveda. and tongue insensibility (jihvājaḍya)Stiffness or numbness of the tongue, cf. ibid. ayurveda. vanish. Also, consumed venom does not trouble him. If the mind is here, [it] becomes stable.

[ 11. Eighth Cakra]

Now [there] exists the eighth cakra having one hundred petals located at the aperture of Brahman.The brahmarandhra, commonly referred to as the ``aperture of Brahmā/Brahman'', is a minute aperture atop the cranium near the fontanelle. Its nomenclature draws from the conviction articulated in ancient Upaniṣads, postulating it as a veritable portal enabling the individual soul (ātman) to transcend corporeal confines and converge with the boundless universal consciousness (brahman. The teacher is the deity. Consciousness is the power. Virāṭ is the Ṛṣi, the witness above everything. That which is made of consciousness is associated with the state beyond the fourth state. It has all colors. It has all matrices. It has all petals. Virāṭ is the body. Standing still is the state. Wisdom is the speech. The "I am that" [expression] (sohaṃ) is the Veda. Unsurpassed is the place. A thousandfold recitation of the non recited; 1000; 2 ghaṭis, 46 palās, 40 akṣaras. The count of all silent mutterings [per day] is 21600. In this way, it carries on day and night. He who knows the breath is a learned person. With the sound "sa", he exhales. With the sound "ha", he inhales again: "I am he, he is I". Because of that, the embodied soul constantly utters the Mantra. ``The (divine) seat of Jālaṃdhara'' is the designation of its lotus. Find parallels where Jālandhara is on top of the head. See, for example, Saubhagya Upaniṣad or SSP for a similar conception! [It is] the place of the accomplished person. \fill

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. l. 3): tanmadhye gnidhūmrāreṣākārā ādimadhyaṃtarahitā puruṣasya mūrttir asti |tanmadhye 'gnidhūmākārarekhā yādṛśī/ yādṛśy ekā puruṣasya mūrtir vartate/ tasyā nādir nānto 'sti/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. l. 4): tasyāḥ dhyānakartuḥtasyā mū:rter dhyānakaraṇāt pratyakṣaniraṃtaraṃ puruṣasyākāśe gamāgamau bhavataḥ/ \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. ll. 4 5): pṛthivyāṃ sthitāv api pṛthvī kṛtabādho na bhavati | trikālikajñānaṃ pratyakṣaṃ bhavati | āyurvṛddiḥ liṃgaśarīreṇa sarvatra pratyakṣaṃ gamāgamo bhavati |pṛthvīmadhye sthitasyāpi pṛthvībādho na bhavati/ sakalaṃ pratyakṣaṃ nirantaraṃ paśyati pṛthagbhavati/ atiśayenāyur vardhate// \vfill

nakaraṇāt pratyakṣaniraṃtaraṃ (ceteri) ] dhyānakāraṇāt pratyakṣaṃ niraṃtaraṃ (B E)

sthitasyāpi (ceteri) ] sthitāv api (Y)
pṛthvībādho (E L) ] pṛtvībādho (B), pṛthaka (P), pṛthvī bādhoko (U2), pṛthvī kṣato bādho (X)
na bhavati (ceteri) ] bhavati (P)
sakalaṃ pratyakṣaṃ nirantaraṃ ] sakalāpratyakṣaṃ nirantaraṃ (X), sakalāḥ pratyakṣaṃ niraṃtara (B L), sakalān pratyakṣaṃ niraṃtaraṃ (E), om. (P U2)

rdhate (ceteri) ] vardhayate (B L)
\nolinenumbers \smallskip [ 12. Ninth Cakra] \linenumbers

\approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. ll. 6 11): brahmaraṃdhre eva śatadalacakropari mahāśūnyacakraṃ mahāsiddhacakraṃ pūrṇagiricakraṃ iti saṃjñakaṃ sahasradalaṃ cakraṃ asti | tad upari kiṃcin nāsti | tac cakraṃ atiraktaṃ ūrdhvamukhaṃ sakalaśobhāspadaṃ anekakalyāṇapūrṇaṃ mano vācā ma gocara parimalo petaṃ |cf. YSv (PT p. 833): navaman tu mahāśūnyaṃ cakran tu tatparātparam | tad upari paraṃ kiñcin nāsti kiñcin mahāparam | mahācakraṃ siddhacakraṃ pūrṇagauryādisaṃjñakam | tanmadhye varttate padmaṃ sahasradalam adbhutam |cf. SSP 2.9 (Ed. pp. 32): navamam ākāśacakraṃ soḍaśadalakamalam ūrdhvamukham | tanmadhye karṇikāyāṃ trikūṭākārāṃ tad ūrdhvaśaktiṃ tāṃ paramaśunyāṃ dhyāyet | tatraiva pūrṇagiripīṭhaṃ sarveṣṭasiddhipradaṃ bhavati |idānīṃ navamacakrasya bhedāḥ kathyante/ tasya mahāśūnyacakreti saṃjñā/ tad upary aparaṃ kimapi nāsti/ tad eva ma:hāsiddhacakraṃ kathyate/ tasya pūrṇagiripīṭham iti etādṛśaṃ nāma/ tasya mahāśūnyacakramadhye ūrdhvamukham atiraktavarṇaṃ sakalaśobhāspadaṃ anekakalyāṇapūrṇaṃ sahasradalaṃ ekaṃ kamalaṃ vartate/

navama (ceteri) ] navamaṃ (B), navamaś° (U1)
bhedāḥ (ceteri) ] bheda (N2)
kathyante (ceteri) ] kathyate (L B N2 U2)
mahāśūnya (ceteri) ] mahāśūnye (L B N1), om. (U2)
cakreti (X) ] °cakram iti (E P), cakram iti (L B), om. (U2)
saṃjñā (ceteri) ] om. (U2)
tad upar (E P B) ] tad upari (ceteri), om. (U2)
y aparaṃ (ceteri) ] om. (B L U2)
kimapi (ceteri) ] kiṃ api (X), om. (U2)
tasya (ceteri) ] tasya cakrasya (X), madhye tasya (U2)
pīṭha (B P L U2) ] pīṭha (E), om. (ceteri)
m iti (P U2) ] iti saṃjñā (B L), om. (ceteri)
etādṛśaṃ (ceteri) ] etadṛśaṃ (E), ekādaśaṃ (U2)
nāma (ceteri) ] nāmaḥ (U1)
cakramadhye (X) ] °cakrasya madhye (B E L P), °cakrasya (U2)
ūrdhvamukham a (X) ] ūrdhmukham (E P L), urdhvamukham (U2), ūrdhvamukhem (B)
tiraktavarṇaṃ (X) ] iti raktavarṇaṃ (B E L), iti raktavarṇa° (P), ativarṇaṃ (U2)
śobhāspadaṃ (ceteri) ] °śobhāspadam (E), °śobhanāsyadaṃ (U2)
anekakalyāṇapūrṇaṃ (ceteri) ] °pūrṇa° (B N2)
ekaṃ (ceteri) ] eka° (D), om. (U1)
vartate (ceteri) ] vartato (B)

In its middle [is] something like a streak having the form of smoke and fire. Such a single [divine] form of the person (puruṣa) exists [there]. Of her exists no end nor a beginning. Due to meditation on the form, uninterrupted observation of both the coming and going of the soul in space occurs. Affliction from the earth element does not arise [anymore] even if one is in the middle of the earth. He constantly sees everything in front of his eyes and becomes separated [from the material world?]. The force of life increases eminently.

[ 12. Ninth Cakra]

Now, the divisions of the ninth cakra are explained. The designation of it is ``the cakra of the great void''. Above that, there is no other. Therefore it is declared the cakra of the great perfection. [Another] such name is ``(divine) seat of Pūrṇagiri''. In the middle of the mahāśūnyacakra exists one lotus facing upward, very red, with a thousand petals an abode of brilliance and wholeness.The ninefold cakra system of the Yogatattvabindu can also be identified in the Yogasvarodaya, the Siddhasiddhāntapaddhati, the Yogakarṇikā. Another text that included the same cakra system and probably quoted the Siddhasiddhāntapaddhati without reference and a few redactions is the saubhagya: atha hainaṃ devā ūcurnavacakravivekam anubrūhīti | tatheti sa hovāca ādhāre brahmacakraṃ trirāvṛttaṃ bhagamaṇḍalākāram | tatra mūlakande śaktiḥ pāvakākāraṃ dhyāyet | tatraiva kāmarūpapīṭhaṃ sarvakāmapradaṃ bhavati | ity ādhāracakram | dvitīyaṃ svādhiṣṭhānacakraṃ ṣaḍdalam | tanmadhye paścimābhimukhaṃ liṅgaṃ pravālāṅkurasadṛśaṃ dhyāyet | tatraivoḍyāṇapīṭhaṃ jagadākarṣaṇasiddhidaṃ bhavati | tṛtīyaṃ nābhicakraṃ pañcāvartaṃ sarpakuṭilākāram | tanmadhye kuṇḍalinīṃ bālārkakoṭiprabhāṃ tanumadhyāṃ dhyāyet | sāmarthyaśaktiḥ sarvasiddhipradā bhavati | maṇipūracakraṃ hṛdayacakram | aṣṭadalamadhomukham | tanmadhye jyotirmayaliṅgākāraṃ dhyāyet | saiva haṃsakalā sarvapriyā sarvalokavaśyakarī bhavati | kaṇṭhacakraṃ caturaṅgulam | tatra vāme iḍā candranāḍī dakṣiṇe piṅgalā sūryanāḍī tanmadhye suṣumnāṃ śvetavarṇāṃ dhyāyet | ya evaṃ vedānāhatā siddhidā bhavati | tālucakram | tatrāmṛtadhārāpravāhaḥ | ghaṇṭikāliṅgamūlacakrarandhre rājadantāvalambinīvivaraṃ daśadvādaśāram | tatra śūnyaṃ dhyāyet | cittalayo bhavati | saptamaṃ bhūcakramaṅguṣṭhamātram | tatra jñānanetraṃ dīpaśikhākāraṃ dhyāyet | tadeva kapālakandavāksiddhidaṃ bhavati | ājñācakram aṣṭamam | brahmarandhraṃ nirvāṇacakram | tatra sūcikāgṛhetaraṃ dhūmraśikhākāraṃ dhyāyet | tatra jālandharapīṭhaṃ mokṣapradaṃ bhavatīti parabrahmacakram | navamam ākāśacakram | tatra ṣoḍaśadalapadmam ūrdhvamukhaṃ tanmadhyakarṇikātrikūṭākāram | tanmadhye ūrdhvaśaktiḥ | tāṃ paśyandhyāyet | tatraiva pūrṇagiripīṭhaṃ sarvecchāsiddhisādhanaṃ bhavati | Yet another text that incorporates a system of nine places in the context of a technique \ldots

cf. YSv (PT p. 833): ūrddhvavakraṃ mahāvaktre (mahāvaktraṃ YK 1.274) varṇaśobhāpadaṃ mahat | sarvakalyāṇasampūrṇamasya tulyaṃ na vidyate | parimāṇaṃ vaktam (vaktum YK 1.275) asya manasā vacasā na hi | trikoṇakarṇikā tatra (°tantraṃ YK 1.276) varttate jagad īśvari | kalā saptadaśī tatra varttate parameśvari | nirañjanakalā sā tu koṭisūryasamaprabhā | koṭicandraprabhā caiva śītoṣṇādivivarjitā | asya dhyānāt sādhakasya manoduḥkhaṃ bhaven na hi | \approx Yogasaṃgraha (IGNCA 30020 folio 2r. ll. 9 11): tat kamalamadhye trikoṇākarṇikā | tasyāṃ karṇikāyāṃ saptadaśī niraṃjanarūpā koṭisūryaprabhā satī uṣṇabhava hīnā koṭicandrasamasītalaikākalāsti | tasyāṃ anaṃta paramānaṃtaparamānaṃdānāṃ sthānaṃ tasyāḥ kalāyā dhyānakaraṇāt sādako yadyādi śati tatra bhavati|yasya parimāṇaṃ vaktuṃ manasā vacasā na gocaraḥ/ tasya kamalasya madhye trikoṇarūpaikā karṇikā vartate// tatkarṇikāmadhye saptadaśī ekā nirañjanarūpā kalā varttate/ koṭisūryasamaprabhaṃ kalāyās tejo vartate/ param u:ṣṇabhāvo nāsti/ koṭicandrasamaprabhaṃ śītalaparaṃ bhāvo nāsti/ asyāḥ kalāyā dhyānakaraṇāt sādhakasya duḥkhaṃ na bhavati/ atra sthāne 'haṃ devatā// sohaṃ śaktiḥ// ātmāṛṣiḥ// mokṣo mārgaḥ// ahaṃ brahmordhvaṃ// ahaṃ cakra iti// agnicakre sakāro bhavati// prāṇī rūḍho bhavej jīva ārohaty avarohati// bhavaguhā sthānaṃ// pitaṃ varṇaṃ// koṭisūryapratikāśaṃ tejaḥ// sadoditā prabhā// śivo devatā// mūlamāyā śaktiḥ// harātmā:layāvasthā// dhvanisthirānādātmako 'khaṇḍadvaniḥ// aghorā mudrā// mūlā māyā// prakṛtir dehaḥ// vāṅmano 'gocaraḥ// niḥprapañcaḥ// niḥsaṃśayaḥ// nistaraṃganirlepalakṣaṃ layo dhyānaḥ samādhiḥ//

yasya (ceteri) ] yasya kamalasya (U2)
parimāṇaṃ vaktuṃ ] parimalo (ceteri)
manasā vacasā (B D L P N1 N2) ] manaso vacaso (E), vacasā manasā (U1), manasā vācā (U2)
na (ceteri) ] om. (L)

ekā (ceteri) ] om. (E)
samaprabhaṃ (ceteri) ] samaprabhā (L B U2), samaprabha (P), sadṛṣaprabhaṃ (U1)
param u: (E U1 U2) ] paraṃ (U1), para (N2), parim (ceteri)
ṣṇabhāvo (ceteri) ] uṣṇabhavo (B L P), auṣṇabhāvo (D), udbhavo (E)
samaprabhaṃ (N1 N2 D) ] °samaprabhā (Y), °samaṃ prabhaṃ (U1), om. (L)
śītalaparaṃ (N1 D) ] śītalaṃ paraṃ (ceteri), śītalapara (N2), om. (L)
bhāvo (ceteri) ] śītabhāvo (E P B), śītalabhāvo (U2), om. (L)
asyāḥ (ceteri) ] asyā (N2 U2)
kalāyā (N2 U1) ] kalāyāḥ (N1 D), kalāyā (E B L), kalāyāḥ (U2), om. (P)
karaṇāt sā (X) ] °yogāt (Y)
dhakasya (ceteri) ] sādhaka° (N2)
na (ceteri) ] om. (B L)
sthāne ] stāne (U2)
mokṣo ] mokṣa° (U2)
