tādṛśam e (ceteri) ] etādṛśom (U2)
kaṃ (ceteri) ] eka (E P N2)
icchā (ceteri) ] icchāyāḥ (N1), om. (E)
kriyā (ceteri) ] om. (E N1)
māyā (ceteri) ] om. (E)
prakṛtiḥ (ceteri) ] prakṛtī (P), prakṛti° (U1), om. (E)
vācā ] vāca (X), vācāḥ (P B), vācyaḥ (L), bhāvaḥ (U2), om. (E)

The SSP 1.54 associates the five final qualities on this page as qualities of the upper category of vyaktaśakti. Each item of these five qualities has five sub qualities. This results in a total of twenty five qualities of vyaktaśakti. Here, however, the term vyaktaśakti was probably lost in transmission and is not reflected in any of the Yogatattvabindu's witnesses.

[ 53. Pentad of the Kula] Immediately afterwards, the divisions of the pentad of the kulaThe term kula in this context must be understood as śakti in contrast to akula, which is śiva. Cf. l. 2. Add quotes of SSP here! are taught: sattva, rajas, tamas, time and the living soul. In the case of sattva, the qualities are: compassion, religious duty, pity, devotion and confidence. The qualities of rajas are: renunciation, enjoyment, sexuality, self interest and accumulation of possessions. The qualities of tamas are: conflict, struggle, grief, bond, cheating. Furthermore, the qualities of time are: inciting, arranging, moving around, negligence [and] mental disorder. The qualities of the living soul are: the state of waking, the state of sleeping, the state of deep sleep, [and the] state of liberation. Furthermore such unique knowledge is generated: desire, action, illusion, nature, speech.In the sources these qualities are associated with vyaktaśakti which is the manifested form of the universal energy.

cf. SSP 1.55 (Ed. p. 18): unmādo vāsanā vāñchā cintā ceṣṭeti pañcaguṇecchā |cf. YSv (PT p. 847): āśātṛṣṇāspṛhākāṅkṣāmithyāntaṃ prakṛter iti | unmādo vāsanā vāñchā cekṣitā ca guṇāḥ priye |icchayāḥ/ pañcaguṇāḥ/ unmādaḥ vāsanā// vāñchā// cittaṃ// ceṣṭā// cf. SSP 1.56 (Ed. p. 18): smaraṇam udyogaḥ kāryaṃ niścayaḥ svakulācāra iti pañcaguṇā kriyā |cf. YSv (PT p. 847): śaraṇaṃ satkulācāraḥ kāryaniścaya ucyate | kriyāyāḥ pañcaguṇāḥ/ smaraṇaṃ// udyamaḥ// udvegaḥ// kāryaniścayaḥ// satkulācāratvaṃ// cf. SSP 1.57 (Ed. p. 18): mado mātsaryaṃ dambhaḥ kṛtrimatvam asatyam iti pañcaguṇā māyā |māyāyāḥ pañcaguṇāḥ/ madaḥ// mātsaryaḥ// daṃbhaḥ// kīrtiḥ// asatyabhāvaḥ// cf. SSP 1.58 (Ed. p. 19): āśā tṛṣṇā spṛhā kāṅkṣā mithyeti pañcaguṇā prakṛtiḥ |prakṛteḥ pañcaguṇāḥ/ āśā// tṛṣṇā// spṛhā// kāṃkṣā// mithyātvaṃ// cf. SSP 1.59 (Ed. p. 19): parā paśyantī madhyamā vaikharī mātṛketi pañcaguṇā vāk | iti vyaktiśaktipañcaviṃśatiguṇāḥ |vācāyā pañcaguṇāḥ/ parā// paśyantī// madhyamā// vaikharī// mātṛkā//

icchayāḥ (D E N1 U1 U2) ] ichāyā (B L P), icchayā (N2)
unmādaḥ ] unmany (X E L), unmaya (P), unmayā (B), unmanyaṃ (U2)
vāsanā (ceteri) ] avāsanā (L), vāsanāḥ (U2), avasthā (E), ichā kriyā māyā prakṛti vāca ichāyāḥ paṃcaguṇāḥ unmany (U1)
vāñchā (ceteri) ] vāṃcha (B L P), om. (U1)
cittaṃ (E L) ] caittaṃ (N1 N2), caita (D), krittaṃ (B), vittaṃ (P), om. (U1)
ceṣṭā (N1 N2 D) ] ceṣṭa (P L), ceṣṭāḥ (U2), ccoṣṭhā (B), veṣṭanam vibhramaḥ (E), om. (U1)
kriyāyāḥ (ceteri) ] kriyāyā (B L N2)
udyamaḥ (ceteri) ] udyama (N2)
udvegaḥ (D E N1 U2) ] udvega (B L P N2)
kāryaniścayaḥ (ceteri) ] kārya | niścayaḥ (N1)
māyāyāḥ (B E U2) ] māyāyāṃ (P), māyāyā (ceteri)
pañcaguṇāḥ (B E L) ] guṇāḥ (P N1 N2 U2), guṇā (D)
madaḥ (ceteri) ] mada (E N2)
mātsaryaḥ (D N1) ] mātsaryaṃ (P U2), mātsarya (B L N2), mātsaryādayaḥ (E)
daṃbhaḥ (ceteri) ] raṃbhaḥ (B L), daṃbha (N2)
kīrtiḥ (ceteri) ] kīrtiś ca (D N1 N2)
asatyabhāvaḥ (ceteri) ] asatyabhāvāḥ (E)
prakṛteḥ (E) ] prakṛter (P U2), prakṛte (ceteri)
pañcaguṇāḥ (E) ] guṇāḥ (ceteri)
kāṃkṣā (ceteri) ] kākṣā (D), bhikṣā (P)
vācāyā (ceteri) ] vācā (D), vācaḥ (U2)
pañcaguṇāḥ (B E L) ] pañcaguṇaḥ (U2), guṇāḥ (ceteri)
paśyantī (ceteri) ] paśyanti (B L N1 N2 U2)
mātṛkā (ceteri) ] mātṛkāḥ (U2)

Since the first item on the list is obviously corrupted and does not suite the context, I conjectured according to the sources.

The list of the five qualities of icchā (right after the words ichāyāḥ paṃcaguṇāḥ unmany), kriyā, māyā, prakṛti are omitted in englishU1. englishU1 continues its evidence from the last two items of the five qualities of vācā onwards. These omissions will not be recorded in the apparatus criticus.

\vfill \nolinenumbers [ 53. Karma, Kāma, Moon, Sun and Fire] \linenumbers

cf. SSP 1.60 (Ed. p. 19): karmaḥ kāmaś candraḥ sūryo 'gnir iti pratyakṣakaraṇapañcakamtad anantaram etādṛśaṃ jñānam utpadyate/ karma// kāmaḥ// candraḥ// sūryaḥ// agniḥ// etat pañcakaṃ pratyakṣaṃ karttavyaṃ/ cf. SSP 1.61 (Ed. p. 19): śubham aśubhaṃ yaśo 'pakīrtir adṛṣṭaphalasādhanam iti pañcaguṇaṃ karma |tatra karmaṇaḥ pañcaguṇāḥ/ śubhaṃ// aśubhaṃ// yaśaḥ// apakīrtiḥ// iṣṭaphalasādhānaṃ//

nantaram e (E L U2) ] anaṃtaraṃ (ceteri)
tpadyate (ceteri) ] utpādyate (D N1 N2)
karma (ceteri) ] karmaḥ (U2)
kāmaḥ (ceteri) ] kāma (B L P N2 U1)
candraḥ (E N1 U2) ] candra (ceteri)
sūryaḥ (ceteri) ] sūrya (N2 U1)
agniḥ (E U2) ] agni (N2), agnī (U1), āgniḥ (ceteri)
karmaṇaḥ (ceteri) ] karmaṇā (B P), karmaṇa° (N2), karmaṇāṃ (L)
śubhaṃ (ceteri) ] śubha (D U1), om. (E)
aśubhaṃ (ceteri) ] °aśubha° (U1), om. (E P)
yaśaḥ (ceteri) ] yasa (N2), om. (E)
apakīrtiḥ (ceteri) ] apakīrtti (N2), āvakīrtiḥ (U1), om. (E)
iṣṭaphalasādhānaṃ (ceteri) ] om. (E)

The five qualities of desire are: madness, mental imprint, wish, thinking, activity. The five qualities of action are: memory, effort, agitation, decision about the activity, [and] adherence to the conduct of the right lineage. The qualities of illusion are: intoxication, envy, fraud, fame, the state of untruth. The five qualities of nature are: space, thirst, desire, striving [and] infatuation. [ 53. Karma, Kāma, Moon, Sun and Fire] Immediately after [that], knowledge about the following things is generated: action, desire, moon, sun, and fire. The direct perception of this pentad shall be done. Among those, the five qualities of Karma are: salvation, calamity, honour, disgrace [and] bringing about the desired result.

cf. SSP 1.62 (Ed. p. 20): ratiḥ prītiḥ krīḍā kāmanā 'turateti pañcaguṇaḥ kāmaḥ |kāmasya guṇāḥ/ ratiḥ// prītiḥ// krīḍā// kāmanā// anuratā// idānīṃ candrasya ṣodaśakalāḥ kathyante/ cf. SSP 1.63 (Ed. p. 20): ullolā kallolinī uccalantī unmādinī taraṃgiṇī śoṣiṇī alampaṭā pravṛttiḥ laharī lolā lelihānā prasarantī pravāhā saumyā prasannā plavantī | evaṃ candrasya ṣoḍaśa kalāḥ | saptadaśī kalā nivṛttiḥ | sā 'mṛtakalā |ullolā// kallolinī// uccalantī// unmādinī// poṣayaṃtī// laṃpaṭā// laharī// lolā// lelihānā// prasarantī// pravṛttiḥ// sravantī// pravāhā// saumyā// prasannā// candrasya saptadaśī kalā vartate/ tasyā nāma nivṛttiḥ sā 'mṛtakalā kathyate/ cf. SSP 1.64 (Ed. p. 20): tāpinī grāsikā ugrā ākuñcinī śoṣiṇī prabodhinī smarā ākarṣiṇī tuṣṭivardhinī urmirekhā kiraṇavatī prabhāvatīti dvādaśa kalāḥ sūryasya | trayodaśī svaprakāśatā nijakalā |idānīṃ sūryasya dvādaśakalāḥ kathyante/ tāpinī// grāsikā ugrā// ākuñcinī// śoṣiṇī// prabodhinī// ghasmarā// ākarṣiṇī// tuṣṭivardhinī// ūrmirekhā// kiraṇavatī// prabhāvatī// sūryasya trayodaśī kalā vidyate/ tasyāḥ saṃjñā nijakalā svaprakāśā ca/ cf. SSP 1.65 (Ed. p. 21): dīpikā rājikā jvalanī visphuliṃginī pracaṇḍā pācikā raudrī dāhikā rāgiṇī śikhāvatī ity agner daśa kalāḥ | ekādaśī kalā jyotiḥ |idānīm agnisaṃbaṃdhinyo kathyante/ dīpikā// rājikā// jvalanī// visphuliṅginī// pracaṇḍā// pācikā// raudrī// dāhikā// rāgiṇī// śikhāvatī// agner ekādaśī nijakalā jyotiḥ saṃjñā vartate//

kāmasya (ceteri) ] kāmaḥsya (U2)
ratiḥ (ceteri) ] rati° (N2 U1)
prītiḥ (ceteri) ] °prīti° (X)
kāmanā (ceteri) ] kāmanāḥ (P), kāminā (B), kāminy (L)
anuratā (D N1) ] ānuratā (U1), anurajā (N2), anuraktatā (L), anurattutā (P), anustutā (B E)
ṣodaśakalāḥ (ceteri) ] ṣoḍaśa (L), saptadaśakalā (U2)
kathyante (ceteri) ] kathyate (B L), vartaṃte || tasyānāmāni || ṣoḍaśakalā kathyaṃte || (U2)
ullolā ] hallolā (D P N1 N2 U1), hallolāḥ (U2), hullātvā (L), dullālā (B), dallolā (E)
kallolinī (ceteri) ] kallolini (U1), kalloli (N2)
uccalantī ] uścalinī (E P), ucaṃlini (B), uchaṃlini (L), uchalanī (U1), ucchṛlinī (U2), om. (D N1 N2)
unmādinī (ceteri) ] unmādani (U1)
poṣayaṃtī (E P) ] poṣayanti (D N1 N2), poṣāyaṃtī (B L), poṣayanī (U1), poṣayati (U2)
laṃpaṭā (E P U1 U2) ] lapaṃṭāḥ (B), lapaṭāḥ (L), lapaḍā (D N1 N2)
lolā (ceteri) ] lolāḥ (U2)
lelihānā (ceteri) ] lelihānāḥ (U2), lelihā (B L)
prasarantī (ceteri) ] prasaraṃti (U1 U2)
pravṛttiḥ (ceteri) ] pravṛttī (B), prakṛtī (L)
sravantī (ceteri) ] sravaṃti (U2), plavantī (E)
pravāhā (ceteri) ] pravāhāḥ (U2), mavāhā (B L), pravaṃtī śvāḥ (U1)
saumyā (ceteri) ] saumyāḥ (U2), saumya (U1), somyā (B L)
prasannā (ceteri) ] prasannāḥ (U2)
saptadaśī (ceteri) ] saptadṛśī (U2), saptadaśamī (B E)
kalā (ceteri) ] kā (U1)
tasyā (ceteri) ] tasya (P), tasyāḥ (U2)
nāma (ceteri) ] nāmāni || (U2)
nivṛttiḥ (U1) ] nivṛtti (B E L P), naivṛttiḥ (N1 N2), naivṛttaiḥ (D), vṛttiḥ (U2)
sā 'mṛtakalā (D N1 N2) ] sā mṛta (U1), sametaḥ || kalāḥ || (U2), sametakalā (B E L P)
kathyate (ceteri) ] kathyante (U2)
dvādaśakalāḥ (P U2) ] dvādaśakalā (B D L N1 N2 U1), kalāḥ (E)
kathyante (ceteri) ] kathyate (B L N2)
tāpinī ] tāpanī (P), tāpani (B L), tapanī (D E N1 N2 U2), tapani (U1)
grāsikā ] grāsakā (ceteri), grāsaka (B L P)
ākuñcinī ] ākuṃcanī (X), ākocanī (B L P), akocanī (U2)
śoṣiṇī (P) ] śoṣaṇī (ceteri)
ākarṣiṇī (E) ] ākarṣayatī (U2), ākarṣayaṃti (U1), ākarṣayaṃtī (ceteri)
tuṣṭivardhinī (E P) ] tuṣṭivardhanī (B L), tuṣṭi, varddhanī (N1), tuṣṭi varddhanī (D N2), tuṣṭiḥ varddhanī (U2)
ūrmirekhā (ceteri) ] kūrmīreṣā (E), kurmmīrekhā (P), ūrmī || rekhā (U2)
kiraṇavatī (E U2) ] kiraṇāvatī (D P N1 N2), kīrṇāvatī (B L), kīrṇavatī (U1)
prabhāvatī ] prabhavati (B E), prabhūtavatī (P U2), prabhutavati (L), prabhutavatī (ceteri)
tasyāḥ (D U1) ] tasyā (U2), tasya (ceteri)
saṃjñā (X) ] nāma (E L P), namaḥ (B), nāmāni (U2)
nijakalā (ceteri) ] nijakalāṃ (D N1 N2)
idānīm a (ceteri) ] idānīṃ (U2)
gnisaṃbaṃdhinyo (E P) ] agnīsaṃbaṃdhinī (ceteri), agnīsaṃbaṃdhinīṃ (U1)
dīpikā (ceteri) ] dīpikar (U1)
rājikā ] jārakā (D N1 N2), jakā (U1), om. (ceteri)
jvalanī ] jvālāviḥ (U1), jvālā (ceteri)
pācikā (E) ] pācakā (D N1 N2), pāvakā (ceteri)
dāhikā (E) ] dāhakā (D P N1 N2 U2), dāhaka (B L U1)
rāgiṇī ] rāvaṇī (Y), rāvaṇi (X)
agner e (ceteri) ] agne (B L U1)
kādaśī (D E P U2) ] ekādaśi (ceteri)
saṃjñā (ceteri) ] saṃjñakā (D N1 N2)
vartate (ceteri) ] om. (D N1 N2)

The qualities of desire are: lust, satisfaction, play, sexual desire, and falling in love. Now, the sixteen digits of the moon are taught: 1. Ullola (she who is violently moving), 2. Kallolinī (she who is surging), 3. Uccalantī (she who is springing), 4. Unmādinī (she who is intoxicating), 5. Taraṅginī (she who is waving), 6. Poṣayanti (she who is nourishing), 7. Laṃpaṭā (she who is lustful), 8. Laharī (she who is billow), 9. Lolā (she who is oscillating), 10. Lelihānā (she who is darting out), 11. Prasarantī (she who is spreading), 12. Pravṛttiḥ (she who is appearing), 13. Sravantī (she who flows), 14. Pravāhā (she who is pulling), 15. Saumyā (she who is dedicated to Soma), 16. Prasannā (she who is pleasing). A seventeenth digit of the moon exists. Her name is Nivṛtti (inactivity), [and] she is taught to be the digit of the nectar of immortality. Now, the twelve digits of the sun are taught. 1. Tāpinī (she who is heating), 2. Grāsikā (she who is seizing), 3. Ugrā (she who is fierce), 4. Ākuñcinī (she who is contracting), 5. Śoṣiṇī (she who is desiccating), 6. Prabodhinī (she who is awakening), 7. Ghasmarā (she who is voracious), 8. Ākarṣiṇī (she who is attracting), 9. Tuṣṭivarddhinī (she who is satisfying), 10. Ūrmirekhā (she who is a row of waves), 11. Kiraṇavatī (she who is radiating), 12. Prabhāvatī (she who is shining). The thirteenth digit of the sun is to be known. Her technical designation is Nijakalā (inherent digit) and Svaprakāśā (self luminous).

[ 54. The Majesty of Yoga]

cf. YSv (PT p. 847): idānīṃ yogamāhātmyaṃ kathyate yad bhavet tataḥ |idānīṃ yogasya māhātmyaṃ kathyate/ cf. YSv (PT p. 847): guror anugrahāc chāstrapāṭhād ācāratas tathā | vedāntārtharahasyārthasarvajñānādupāsanāt | āsanād dhāraṇād dhyānāl layaṣaṭkarmasādhanāt | āsanāc caturaśītivairāgyatyāgasambhavāt |guror anugrahāt// śāstrasya paṭhanāt// ācārakaraṇāt// vedāntarahasya śravaṇāt// dhyānakaraṇāt// layasādhanāt// upavāsakaraṇāt// caturaśītyāsanasādhanāt// vairāgyasyotpatteḥ// vairāgyakaraṇāt// cf. YSv (PT p. 848): haṭhayogād varauṣadhyāt mudrāsādhanamānataḥ | vanavāsād bahukleśāt tathā mantrādisādhanāt |haṭhayogasyakaraṇāt// iḍāpiṅgalayoḥ pavanadhāraṇāt// mahāmudrādidaśamudrāsādhanāt// maunakaraṇāt// vanavāsāt// bahutarakleśakaraṇāt// bahutarakālaṃ yantramantrādisādhanāt// tapakaraṇāt// cf. YSv (PT p. 848): bahudānatapastīrthasevanād dānaśikṣaṇāt | sandhyātrayagraheṇātha ṣaḍadarśagrahaṇāt tathā | śiromuṇḍagato nyāsād yogatattvañ ca vidyate |bahutarārthādānāt// tīrthasevākaraṇāt// āśramācārapālanāt// saṃnyāsagrahaṇāt// ṣaḍdarśanagrahaṇāt// siromuṃḍanāt// anyopāyakaraṇāt// yogatattvaṃ na prāpyate/ sa tu yogo gurusevayā prāpyate/

idānīṃ (ceteri) ] idānī (B)
yogasya (ceteri) ] yasya (U1)
māhātmyaṃ (ceteri) ] māhātmaṃ (B L), māhātmya (N2)
kathyate (ceteri) ] kathyaṃte (U2)
guror a (ceteri) ] guru (B L)
nugrahāt (ceteri) ] agrahāt (L)
ācārakaraṇāt (ceteri) ] ācārakathanāt (U2)
dhyānakaraṇāt (ceteri) ] om. (P)
layasādhanāt (X) ] om. (Y)
upavāsakaraṇāt (ceteri) ] om. (P)
caturaśītyāsanasādhanāt (B L P U2) ] caturaśītyāsane sādhanāt (E), caturaśīti āsanasādhanāt (X)
vairāgyasyotpatteḥ (E L N2 U2) ] vairāgyasyotpatte (B), vairāgyasyotpattaḥ (P), vairāgyotpatteḥ (N1 D), vairāgyotpatte (U1)
vairāgya (ceteri) ] nairāśya (P L), nairāśa° (B), nairāśye (E)
haṭha (ceteri) ] haṭa° (B L U1)
yogasya (ceteri) ] yoga° (N1 N2 D)
iḍāpiṅgalayoḥ (ceteri) ] iḍāpiṃgalayāḥ (N2 U1)
pavanadhāraṇāt (E P U1) ] pāvanādhāraṇāt (D N1), pavanādhāraṇāt (N2), pavanādhānākaraṇāt (U2), pāvanāpāvadhyānakaraṇāt (L), om. (B)
mahāmudrādidaśamudrāsādhanāt (ceteri) ] mahāmudrāsādhanāt (U1), mahāmudrādidaśamudrādi daśamūdrasādhanāt (D)
maunakaraṇāt (ceteri) ] maunakaraṇād (N2)
vanavāsāt (ceteri) ] vane vāsāt (D N1 U1), vane vāsāta° (N2)

tapa (ceteri) ] tapaḥ (E P U2)
bahutarārthādānāt (ceteri) ] bahutarārpaṇadānāt (E), bahutarakleśakaraṇāt bahutarakaraṇāt bahutatārthadānāt (P)
tīrthasevākaraṇāt (D N2) ] tīrthasevokaraṇāt (N1), niyamakaraṇāt (U1), om. (ceteri)
āśramācārapālanāt (ceteri) ] āśramācyārapālanāt (U1)
ṣaḍdarśanagrahaṇāt (B E L U1) ] ṣaṭdarśanagrahaṇāt (ceteri)
siromuṃḍanāt (ceteri) ] siromaṃḍanāt (N2), om. (P)
anyopāyakaraṇāt (ceteri) ] om. (P)

Senctence is omitted in englishP.

cf. YSv (PT p. 848): gurupādodakaṃ śiṣṭasevinā satyavādinā | kanyāstrādidṛṣṭipātaharṣagativivarttanāt | ≈ SSP 5.61: gurudṛkpātanāt prāyo dṛḍhānāṃ satyavādināṃ sā sthitir jāyate |gurudṛkpātapātrāṇāṃ dṛḍhānāṃ satyavādinām/ kathanād dṛṣṭipātād vā sāṃnidhyād avalokanāt// 54.1 //

gurudṛkpātapātrāṇāṃ (P N1 N2 U2) ] gurudṛkpāt patrāṇāṃ (L), gurudṛk | pāt | patrāṇāṃ (B), gurudakpātrāṇāṃ (U1), gurudṛkpātapātrāṇo (D), gurukṛpātaḥ pātrāṇāṃ (E)
dṛḍhānāṃ (ceteri) ] om. (L)
satyavādinām (ceteri) ] satyavāridinām (U1)
kathanād dṛ (ceteri) ] upayā° (U1)
ṣṭipātād vā (ceteri) ] viṣapātād (B), viṣapānād (L)
sāṃnidhyād a (P E U2) ] sānidhyāt (B), sānnitdhy (L), sānidhyād (D N1 N2), sānidhyāty (U1)
valokanāt (E L P U1) ] dyavatrokanāt (B), dhyavalokanāt (N1 N2), dhyāvalokanāt (U2), dyavalokanāt (D)

[ 54. The Majesty of Yoga] Now, the majesty of yoga is taught. Because of grace of the teacher, because of studying the teaching, because of execution of good conduct, because of hearing the secret of Vedānta, because of execution of meditation, because of practicing dissolution, because of the execution of fasting, because of practising 84 āsanas, because of the generation of equanimity, because of executing equanimity, because of doing Haṭhayoga, because of holding the breath of the Iḍā and Piṅgalā channels, because of practicing the ten seals [like] the great seal etc., because of [the observation of] silence, because of dwelling in the forest, because of the execution of many defilements?!, because of practicing Mantra and Yantra for a long time, because of austerities, because of giving up a lot of possession, because of frequenting places of pilgrimage, because of protection of the habit of the stages of life, because of undertaking renunciation, because of grasping the six philosophies, because of shaving the head, because of the execution of other means, the reality of yoga is not attained. The [reality of] yoga is truly attained by frequenting the teacher. 54.1 Among the firm, the truthful [and] among those worthy of the teacher's gaze, caused by [the teachers'] narration or caused by [the teachers'] glance, caused by the [mere] proximity [to the teacher] \ldots

≈ YSv (PT. p. 848): prasādāt sadguroḥ samyak prāpnoti paramaṃ padam | na guror adhikaṃ tattvaṃ yat tasmāt paramaṃ padam | ≈ SSP 5.61cd 62ab (Ed. p. 99): prasādāt svaguroḥ samyak prāpyate paramaṃ padaṃ ||61|| ata eva śivenoktam na guror adhikaṃ na guror adhikaṃ na guror adhikaṃ |prasādāt sadguroḥ samyak prāpyate paramaṃ padaṃ/ ata eva vacaḥ proktaṃ na guror adhikaṃ paraṃ// 54.2 //

prasādāt sadguroḥ (ceteri) ] sadguruprasādāt (E), prasādāsya guroḥ (P), prasāt sadguroḥ (B)
prāpyate paramaṃ padaṃ (ceteri) ] paramaṃ padaṃ pāpyate (E)
ata eva (ceteri) ] ata evaṃ (E)
paraṃ (ceteri) ] param (E)

≈ SSP 5.64 (Ed. p. 100): vāṅmātrād vātha dṛkpātāt yaḥ karoti ca tatkṣaṇāt | prasphuṭaṃ śāmbhavaṃ vedhaṃ svasaṃvedyaṃ paraṃ padam |vāṅmātrād vātha dṛkpātād yaḥ karoti śamaṃ kṣaṇāt/ prasphuṭabhrāntihṛttoṣaṃ svacchaṃ vande guruṃ paraṃ// 54.3 //

The verse is omitted in U1. This point marks the beginning of a larger gap in U1. Omissions will not be recorded. The reader will be informed once the evidence of U1 resumes.

≈ SSP 5.64cd 5.65ab (Ed. p. 100): samyag ānandajanakaḥ sadguruḥ so 'bhidhīyate | nimiṣārdhārdhapātād vā yad vā pādāvalokanāt |cf. YSv (PT p. 848): nimeṣārddhena tasyaiva ājñāpālanato bhavet | mahānandaśataprāptis tasmai śrīgurave namaḥ |samyag ānandajananaḥ sadguruḥ sobhidhīyate/ nimeṣārddhaṃ vā tatpādaṃ yad vākyād avalokanāt// 54.4 //

≈ SSP 5.65cd 5.66cd (Ed. pp. 100 101): svātmānaṃ sthiram ādhatte tasmai śrīgurave namaḥ | nānāvikalpaviśrāntiṃ kathayā kurute tu yaḥ | sadguruḥ sa tu vijñeyo na tu mithyāviḍambakaḥ| ≈ YSv (PT p. 848): nānāvikalpavibhrāntināśañ ca kurute tu yaḥ | sadguruḥ sa tu vijñeyo na tu vairaprakalpakaḥ |svātmā sthiratvam āyāti tasmai śrīgurave namaḥ/ nānāvikalpaviśrāntiṃ kathanāt kurute tu yaḥ/ sadguruḥ sa tu vijñeyo na tu vipriyajalpakaḥ// 54.5 //

śrīgurave (ceteri) ] śrīgurubho (L), śrīguru namo (U2)
nānāvikalpaviśrāntiṃ (N1 U2) ] nānāvikalpaṃ viśrāṃtiṃ (D), nānāviplavaviśrāntiḥ (E), nānāvikalpaḥ viśrāṃtiḥ (P), nānāvikalpaviśrāṃti (B L), nānāvikalpaviśrāṃti (N2)

vijñeyo (ceteri) ] vijño (B L)
na tu (ceteri) ] nnu (B L)
vipriyajalpakaḥ (ceteri) ] viprāyajalākaḥ (B L), vai priyajalpakaḥ (E)

54.2 \ldots through the favour of the good teacher, truly one attains the highest place. For this very reason, the advice is stated: There is nothing greater than the teacher. 54.3 Who immediately makes peace of mind from his mere utterance (vāṅmātrād) or by his mere glance (vāṅmātrād), I bow in front of the teacher who is pure, supreme [and] appeases the soul for those who are full of doubt. 54.4 He, who is the progenitor of absolute bliss, is known to be the true teacher. Because of a glance for just half a wink on the [teacher's] feet [or] by [just] talking about [it], \ldots 54.5 \ldots the own self goes into stability, homage to that teacher, who brings all doubts to stop because of [his] advice. He is known to be a true teacher, not an unpleasant disputant.

cf. SSP 5.67 (Ed. p. 101): ata eva paramapadaprāpty arthaṃ sa sadguruḥ sadā vandanīyaḥ |cf. YSv (PT p. 848): ata eva maheśāni sadguruḥ śiva āditaḥ | satyavādī ca sacchīlo gurubhakto dṛḍhavrataḥ |ata eva paramapadaprāpty arthaṃ sadguruḥ sarvadā vandyaḥ/ yaḥ puruṣaḥ satyavādī bhavati/ nirantaraṃ gurusevā rato bhavati/ yasya manasi pāpaṃ na bhavati/ cf. YSv (PT p. 848): svalpācāraratātmā yo dānādiśīlasaṃyutaḥ | kāpaṭyalobhavinyāsau mahāvaṃśasamudbhavaḥ |svācārarataḥ snānādiśīlo bhavati/ kāpaṭyaṃ na bhavati/ yasya vaṃśaparaṃparā jñāyate/ cf. YSv (PT p. 848): īdṛśaḥ sadgurustasya saṅgatau yatnavān bhavet | tad eva manasaḥ śāntiṃ prāpnoti paramaṃ padam |etādṛśasya sadguroḥ saṃgatiḥ karttavyā tena puruṣasya manaḥ śāntiṃ prāpnoti/ atha ca yasya manomadhye sthiraānanda utpadyate/ so 'pi sadguruḥ kathyate/ atha ca ghaṭimātraṃ ghaṭikārdhaṃ ghaṭikācaturthāṃśo vā yasya pārśvaṃ upaviṣṭe satyatādṛṣo bhāvo manomadhye utpadyate/ gatvā vanamadhye sthīyate gṛhaṃ tyajyate so 'pi sadguruḥ kathyate/ kasyāpi duḥkhaṃ na dīyate/ prāṇimātreṇa saha maitrī krīyate/ kasyāpi doṣaṃ na prākāśyate/ so 'pi sadguruḥ kathyate/

englishE omits the three sentences.

ajñānakulaśīlānāṃ yatīnāṃ brahmacāriṇām/ upadeśaṃ na gṛṇhīyād anyathā narakaṃ dhruvaṃ// 54.6 //

upadeśaṃ (ceteri) ] upadeśo (P U2)
gṛṇhīyād a (E P L) ] gṛhītyāsthā | (B), gṛhnīyāt (ceteri)
nyathā (ceteri) ] yadānyathā (B)
narakaṃ (ceteri) ] na narakaṃ (B)
dhruvaṃ (ceteri) ] dhruvam (E P)

yasya vacasi manasi dhṛte sati svātmanaḥ parameśvarasyaikyaṃ bhavati/ etādṛśo manomadhye niścayo bhavati/

vacasi (ceteri) ] cavi (U2)
manasi (ceteri) ] om. (U2)
sati (ceteri) ] sati | (D N1 N2)
parameśvarasyaikyaṃ (E P N1 D U2) ] parameśvarasyaikaṃ (N2), parameśvarasakyaṃ (B L)

Hence, the true teacher is always is to be praised for in order to attain the highest place. That person is a speaker of truth. Uninterrupted devotion for frequenting the teacher arises. He becomes one in whose mind evil does not arise. Being someone who is devoted to good habits, habits such as ceremonial bathing etc. arise. Deceiving does not arise. His noble race is recognized by him.Royalty?! One shall associate with such a true teacher. The mind of such a person attains peace. And he in whose mind arises steady bliss is also called a true teacher. And then such a state of reality is generated of one who is seated at the side of him [the teacher] for a ghaṭikā[1/60th part of a day (24 minutes). siehe Wörterbuch], half a ghaṭikā or a quarter part of a ghaṭikā. He is said to be truly a true teacher. [One who] has left the house and has gone into the forst in order to dwell there. One who does not harm anyone. One who practices loving kindness towards living beings. One who will not expose anyone's badness. He is said to be a true teacher. 54.6 One should not accept teachings from ascetic celibates, from those of unknown lineage and character; otherwise, it would lead to a certain path of hell.This verse is absolute proof that this text was not written for ascetics, but for young princes.!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Unity of the supreme deity and the own self arises, for one who abides calm in mind and speech. Such conviction arises within the mind.

taṃ sadguruṃ jānīyāt/ vikalpa etādṛśo yathā samudramadhye mahattarakallolāḍambaraḥ prapañcavāsanā etādṛśī ya:thodakamadhye mahattaraṅgāḥ/ tādṛśāt saṃsārārṇavād yo nāvā paraṃ pāraṃ prāpayati/ sa sadguruḥ kathyate/ yasya pu:ruṣasya mano 'khaṇḍe paramapade līnaṃ bhavati/ yaḥ puruṣaḥ svīyaṃ kūlaṃ trividhāt tāpān nivartya paramamuktipade rakṣati/ etādṛśaṃ puruṣaṃ śravaṇād darśanāt samagravighnā naśyanti/ dine dine kalyāṇaṃ bhavati niṣkalaṅkā buddhir utpadyate/

\vfill \nolinenumbers [ 55. The Secret of the Scriptures of Yoga] \linenumbers

idaṃ yogaśāstrarahasyaṃ samagraśāstramadhye/ yasya mano yathāndhakārasya madhye dīpasya tejaḥ praviśati/ tathā śāstramadhye tasya manaḥ praviśati/ yasya rājño manomadhye kapaṭaṃ nāsti/ yasmin dṛṣṭe deśakasya trāso na bhavati/ yasya tasya manaḥ śuddhaṃ bhavati/ yasya pṛthivyāṃ kīrtir bhavati/ yasya manomadhye satpuruṣavacanaviśvāso bhavati/ yo rājā sadānandapūrṇo bhavati/ yasya pārśve pratyakṣam anekaṃ manohārivastūni bhavanti/ etādṛśasya rājño 'gre yogarahasyaṃ karttavyaṃ/

yogaśāstrarahasyaṃ (B L N1 U2) ] yogaśāstrarahasya (D N2), yogaśāstreṣu rahasyaṃ (U1), yogaśāstrasya rahasyaṃ (E P)
yasya (ceteri) ] om. (U2)
mano ] manaḥ (E P U1 U2), mana (ceteri), om. (N2)
yathāndhakārasya (ceteri) ] yathāṃdhakāras (N1), yathāṃdhakāra° (D), om. (N2)
madhye (ceteri) ] om. (N2)
dīpasya (ceteri) ] dīpa° (E), om. (N2)
tejaḥ (ceteri) ] om. (N2)
praviśati (D E P N1) ] praviśyati (B L U1), vipraśati (U2), om. (N2)
tathā (ceteri) ] yathā (U2), om. (N2)
śāstramadhye (ceteri) ] om. (B L N2 U1)
tasya manaḥ (D N1 N2) ] manaḥ (P), mano (E U2), om. (B L U1)
praviśati (ceteri) ] om. (B L U1)
yasya (ceteri) ] om. (U1)
manomadhye (ceteri) ] madhye manasi (B L), madhye (E)
kapaṭaṃ (ceteri) ] kalaho (E)
yasmin dṛ (ceteri) ] yasmiṃ (B L N1 D U1)
deśakasya (ceteri) ] darśakasya (U1), deśika° (E)
yasya (U1) ] tasya (ceteri)
yasya (ceteri) ] om. (U1)
pṛthivyāṃ (P L) ] pṛthvyāṃ (B E U2), pṛthivī (D N1 N2), pṛithīvī (U1)
kīrtir (ceteri) ] vītir (E), kīrti (U1), kītīr (U2)
satpuruṣavacanaviśvāso (ceteri) ] satpuruṣavacanaḥ viśvāso (N2), satpuruṣasya vaco viśvāso (E), vacanaviśvabhyāso (U1)
sadānandapūrṇo (ceteri) ] sadānaṃdarūpo (E), sānaṃdapūrṇo (L)
nekaṃ (ceteri) ] aneka° (B L E)
manohārivastūni (E) ] manohārivastu (ceteri)
bhavanti ] tiṣṭhaṃti (E), bhavati (ceteri)
rājño (ceteri) ] rājña (E)
'gre (X) ] ye (B P U2), yad (L), idaṃ (E)
yogarahasyaṃ (ceteri) ] thogarahasyaṃ (B)
karttavyaṃ (N1 N2 U1) ] karttavya (D), kathanīyam (E P), kathyaniyaṃ (B L), kathyate (U2)

One should know this true teacher. The changing thought is like the roar of waves within the ocean. The manifold mental imprints are like the ripples in the water. He who causes to navigates the boat from such an ocean of Saṃsāra to the other shore is called a true teacher. The mind of the person becomes absorbed into the indivisible supreme place. The person situated in the place of supreme liberation who turned away from the threefold misery (adhyātmika, adhibhautika, adhidaivika) protects the own kula (lineage? noble family? tribe?). From hearing [or] from seeing about such a person, all obstacles are destroyed. Day by day, prosperity arises. A flawless intellect arises.

[ 55. The Secret of the Scriptures of Yoga] This is the secret of the scriptures of Yoga within all scriptures of Yoga. Just as the light of a lamp enters into the midst of darkness, similarly his mind enters into the teaching. For such a king, deceit does not exist. [For him], in whose sight fear of the teacher does not arise; [for him] whose mind is pure; [for him] whose fame exists on earth; [for him] in whose mind, there is trust in the words of good individuals; [for him] who is a king always filled with bliss; [for him] by whose side numerous enchanting objects arise in front of his eyes; [for him] this secret of Yoga of such a king is the foremost secret of Yoga that has to be accomplished.

cf. YSv (PT p. 847): idaṃ yogarahasyañ ca na vācyaṃ mūrkhasannidhau || yogadeśas tu tatraiva ||na snehān nabhayāl lobhān namohān nadhānād balāt/ na maitrībhāvān na dāsān nasauṃdaryān na sevanāt// 55.1 //

na (ceteri) ] ni (B L)
snehān na (E P U2) ] śnehān (ceteri)
(E P U2) ] nā (B L), a (D N1 N2)
bhayāl lo (ceteri) ] bhayān (E U1)
bhān na (B D L U1) ] obhān (N1 N2), lno (P), lon (U2)
(ceteri) ] om. (P)
mohān na (ceteri) ] om. (P)
(ceteri) ] om. (P)
dhānād ba (ceteri) ] na dhanād (L), om. (P)
lāt (ceteri) ] balāta (B), om. (P)
na (ceteri) ] om. (P)
maitrībhāvān na (ceteri) ] maitrībhāva (N2), maitrī (D), bhāvān (P)
(N1 U1) ] no (B L P U2), nau (E), nā (N2), om. (D)

(ceteri) ] om. (D)
sauṃdaryān na (ceteri) ] saudaryān (P N2), sauṃdayan (L), om. (D)
(ceteri) ] ni (L), om. (D)
sevanāt (ceteri) ] sevatā (U1)

A lenghty omission starts in D after the word maitrī. The single omissions will not be recorded in the critical apparatus. The reader will be informed once the evidence of D resumes.

sāmānyād agre yogo na kathanīyaḥ/ yaḥ paranindā rato bhavati/ dūrācāro bhavati/ bhrātur mimitrasya ca yogyaṃ vastu na dadāti/ cf. YSv (PT p. 847): stutir nindā na karttavyā sādhunā satyavādinā || yogānadhikāriṇam āha tatraiva ||yo satyaṃ vadati/ yo yogināṃ manomadhye nindāṃ karoti/ cf. PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 847): manomadhye dayā nāsti sadā yaḥ kalahapriyaḥ |yasya manomadhye dayā na bhavati/ yaḥ kalahapriyo bhavati/ svakāryakaraṇe sāvadhāno bhavati/ cf. YSv (PT p. 847): svakāryalobhane śīlo gurukāryaparāṅmukhaḥ | etasmai ca na dātavyaṃ vaktavyaṃ tasya sannidhau |guroḥ kāryakāraṇe 'nādṛto bhavati/ etādṛśasyāgre na yogaḥ kriyate na paṭhyate/ śṛṇvan gītādikān\dd śabdān paśyan rūpaṃ manoharaṃ// jighran gagandhān surabhīn spṛspṛśan span sparśaṃmṛḍupriyaṃ// svādān manoramān khādan bhrāmyan deśān manoramān//

Sentence omitted in englishL.

Both sentences omitted in englishB and englishL.

Sentence omitted in englishD and englishN2.

55.1 Not because of love, not because of fear, not because of greed, not because of gift, not because of friendship, not because of hostility, not because of nobility, not because of service, shall yoga be taught in front of everyone. He, who loves it to blame others; who loves to criticise others; who is behaving badly; who does not gives [single] thing, which benefits friend and brother; who does not speak the truth and despises yoga in spirit; in whose mind compassion does not arise; who is one that has love for quarrel; attention arises for him regarding his selfish intentions; [and] disrespect arises towards the intentions of the teacher. In front of someone like this yoga is neither done nor taught. While hearing the sound of music etc., while seeing heart pounding forms; while smelling fragnent scent, while touching lovely and soft touch, while eating food that pleases the mind, while travelling to beautiful places, \ldots

cf. YSv (PT p. 847): nañubhayatra sambadhyate na vaktavyamityarthaḥ | yogādhikāriṇo'pi tatraiva || bhāvābhāvavinirmuktaḥ sarvagrahavivarjitaḥ | bhakṣamāṇaḥ sumadhuraṃ ramamāṇaḥ svalilayā/ bhāvābhāvavinirmuktaḥ sarvagrāhavivarjitaḥ// 55.2 //

bhakṣamāṇaḥ (L) ] bhakṣamāṇa (B), bhāṣamāṇaḥ (E P U2), bhāṣamāṇasya (N1 N2 U1)
sumadhuraṃ (P U2) ] samaghura° (B), samadhura° (L), madhuraṃ (N1 N2 U1), om. (E)
ramamāṇaḥ (E P U1 U2) ] rasamānaḥ (N1 N2), °ramamāṇaṃ (L), °ramāṇa (B)
bhāvābhāvavinirmuktaḥ (ceteri) ] bhāvābhāvavinirmukto (E), bhāvāvinir muktaḥ (B L)

cf. YSv (PT p. 847): sadānandamayo yogī sadābhyāsī sadā bhavet | viruddhe duḥkhadeśe ca virūpe 'tibhayānake | sadānandamayo yogī sadābhyāsī sadā bhavet/ viruddhe duḥkhadeśe ca virūpe 'tibhayānake// 55.3 //

sadānandamayo (ceteri) ] sadāmayo (B L)
yogī (ceteri) ] yoyogī (L)
sadābhyāsī (ceteri) ] sadābhyāso (U1)
viruddhe (B L N1 N2 U1) ] viruddha° (E P)
duḥkhadeśe ca ] duḥkhade deśe (E P N1 N2 U1), duḥkhe deśe (B), duḥkhadeśe (L)
virūpe (E P N2) ] śovirūpe (B L N1), vivarūpe (U1)
'tibhayānake (E P N1 N2) ] bhayānake (B L U1)

The serse is omitted in englishU2.

≈ YSv (PT p. 847): etad aniṣṭasaṃsparśe nyūnādhike balādhike | evam bhūtasya karmāṇi saṅkalparahitāni ca | ≈ YSv (PT p. 847): utpātarahite deśe kaṇṭakādivivarjite | abhyasyate sadā yogaḥ samaḥ syāt sukhaduḥkhayoḥ |sarvadaiva sadābhyāsaḥ samaḥ syāt sukhaduḥkhayoḥ/ evaṃ bhūtasya karmāṇi saṃkalparahitāni ca// 55.5 //

sarvadaiva (E P N2) ] sarvadeva (B L N1), sarvadaivaṃ (U2)

samaḥ (ceteri) ] sama (N1 U1), mana (N2)

≈ YSv (PT p. 847): evaṃ gacchan svapan paśyan pāpapuṇyairna lipyate | utpannatattvabodhaḥ syāt sadā śīlasya sarvadā | ≈ birch2013 2.36: utpannatattvabodhasya hy udāsīnasya sarvadā | sadābhyāsaratasyaitan naikatrāpy upayujyate ||gacchan nṛṇāṃ ca saṃsparśāt pāpaṃ kurvan na lipyate/ utpannatattvabodhasya udāsīnasya sarvadā// 55.6 //

gacchan nṛ (ceteri) ] gacha (U1)
saṃsparśāt pā (ceteri) ] saṃsparśot (B N1)
paṃ (ceteri) ] pāpaḥ (P), tapaḥ (E)
udāsīnasya (ceteri) ] hy udāsīnasya (E)

55.2 While he consumes excessively sweet things and delights in his own play, he is one who is liberated from both being and non being, and free from all attachments. 55.3 The Yogin that is made of permanent bliss, is always engaged in practice, [even] in land which is hostile and uncomfortable, ugly and extremely terrible. 55.4 In desireable and undesireable contact in tastes like salty etc., evil smells, thorns, etc. [and in] renunciation. 55.5 He who is always truly in permanent practice shall be equanimous towards happiness and suffering. In this way the actions of the great yogin (bhūtasya) are free from desire. 55.6 One does not become tainted by sin going amidst people and engaging in contact, he who has arisen to the awakening of reality, who is in every way equaminous.

≈ YSv (PT p. 847): pare dṛṣṭivilaṃ na syād vividhāni mṛtāni ca | antaḥkaraṇam etasya yogino niṣkriyaṃ [niṣkalā?] tu sa | ≈ birch2013 2.37: tadā dṛṣtiviśeṣāś ca vividhāny āsanāni ca | antaḥkaraṇabhāvaś ca yogino nopayujyate || tadā dṛṣṭiviśeṣaḥ syād vividhāny āsanāni ca/ antaḥkaraṇajā bhavā yogino nopayoginaḥ// 55.7 //

dṛṣṭiviśeṣaḥ (E N1 N2 U2) ] dṛṣṭiviśeṣa (B L P), dṛṣṭir viśeṣa (U1)
vividhāny ā (E N2 U2) ] vidhāny (ceteri)
antaḥkaraṇajā (ceteri) ] aṃtaḥkaraṇayo (U1)
nopayoginaḥ (ceteri) ] nopi yoginaḥ (L U2)

≈ YSv (PT p. 847): sarvadā sahajas tasya niṣkalādhyātmavādinaḥ | yadā prayatnaniṣpādyaṃ grāhyaṃ sarvam akāraṇam | sarvadāsahajas tasya niṣkalādhyātmavedinaḥ/ yatyat prayatnaniṣpādyaṃ tattatsarvam akāraṇāṃ// 55.8 //

vilāsinīnāṃ manohārigītaśravaṇāt// atisundarakāminīnāṃ rūpadarśanāt// kastūrīkarpūragandhayor gra grahaṇāt// śītalakārī atikomalaparavastunaḥ sparśakāraṇāt// atimādhuryaṃ citte karoti/ tādṛśaḥ svādanāt// anekadeśānāṃ sādhvasādhusthānadarśanāt// maitreṇa saha komalavacanāt// śatruṇā saha kāṭhinya vacanāt// yasya manasi harṣo vā dveṣo na bhavati/ sa puruṣa īśvaropadeśako jñeyaḥ/ svalīlayā vadati calati ca bhāvābhāvayoś cittam udāsīnaṃ bhavati/ kasyāṃcid vārttāyāṃ haṭhaṃ na karoti/ yasya manaḥ sahajānande magnaṃ bhavati/

magnaṃ (ceteri) ] añjaṃ (L), saṃjñaṃ (U1)

Evidence of englishB stops here. The last folio of the manuscript is missing.

Evidence of witness englishD resumes from here.

55.7 Then the different gazing points, the various postures and the states born from the sense faculties won't be useful to the yogī. 55.8 For the knower of the undivided supreme self, who is always in the natural state, whatever is to be generated with effort, all of that is without motive. Because of listening to mindblowing musical performance of charming women; because of seeing the form of a extremely beautiful women; from smelling the fragnance of camphor and musk; because of the execution of touching of very soft things, the mind that is free from passion assumes a supremely gentle state within the mental faculty. From such enjoyment; from seeing good and bad places of many countries; from speaking sweet with friends; from speaking with firmness of character to enemies; love and hatred does not arise in his mind. This person is to be known as a teacher of the supreme god. Through his own [divine] play, he speaks and moves. The mind is equanimous in both existence and non existence. It is not even possible to express in words forcefully [how it is] when his mind is immersed in inherent bliss.

tena puruṣeṇa dṛṣṭiḥ sthirā karttavyā/ āsanaṃ dṛḍhaṃ karttavyaṃ/ pavanaḥ sthiraḥ karttavyaḥ/ etādṛśaḥ kaścin niyamaḥ siddhasya soktaḥ noktaḥ/ manaḥpavanābhyāṃ yadā sahajānandaḥ svasvarūpeṇa prakāśyate/ sa sahajayogaḥ kathyate/ rājayogamadhye iti cakravartī nāma kathanaṃ/ iti śrīrāmacandraparamahaṃsaviracitas yogatattvabinduḥ samāptaḥ//

puruṣeṇa (ceteri) ] bhya puruṣeṇa (P), svapuruṣeṇa (D)
dṛṣṭiḥ (ceteri) ] dṛṣṭi° (U1)
karttavyā (ceteri) ] karttavyaṃ (D N1 N2)
āsanaṃ (ceteri) ] āsana° (U1)
karttavyaḥ (ceteri) ] karttavyaṃ (N2)
kaścin niyamaḥ (ceteri) ] kaści nīyamaḥ (U1), kaścin nīyamaḥ (U2)
soktaḥ ] noktaḥ (ceteri)
manaḥpavanābhyāṃ (ceteri) ] manapavanābhyāṃ (L)
sahajānandaḥ (ceteri) ] sahajānaṃda° (E L)
prakāśyate (ceteri) ] prakāśate (U1)
sahajayogaḥ (ceteri) ] sahajayoga (D N1), sahajo yogya (N2), sahayogaḥ (U1)
rājayogamadhye (ceteri) ] rājayogasya madhye (U2), te madhye (E P)
cakravartī (D N2) ] cakravarti (E P L N1 U2), cakravaktya (U1)
nāma (X) ] om. (Y)
kathanaṃ (ceteri) ] kathyate (L U2), madhye iti cakravartye nāma madhye kathanaṃ (U1)
iti śrīrāmacandraparamahaṃsaviracitas yogatattvabinduḥ samāptaḥ ] iti śrīsarvaguṇasampannapaṃḍitasukhānandamiśrasūrisūnupaṇḍitajvālāprasādamiśrakṛtabhāṣāṭīkāsahito rājayoge binduyogaḥ samāptaḥ || śubhamastu || śrīrastu || (E), iti śrīrāmacaṃdraparamahaṃsa viracitas tatvabinduyogasamāptaḥ saṃvat 1867 pauṣakṛṣṇaḥ 12 ravau śubham bhuyāt ||cha|| (P), iti rājamacaṃdraparahaṃsa viracites tatvabiṃduyogasamāptaṃ || śrī kṛṣṇārpaṇam astu || cha || (L), iti śrī paramarahasyāṃ śrīrāmacaṃdraviracitāyāṃ tatvayogabiṃdu samāptaḥ|| ||śrī svasti|| ||saṃvat 837 (N1), iti śrī paramarahasye śrīrāmacaṃdraviracitāyāṃ tatvayogabindu samāptam|| ||śubham|| yadakṣarapadabhraṣṭaṃ mātrāhīnaṃcayaḍ? bhavet|| tat sarvaṃ kṣamya tā?m eva prasīdaparameśvara ||1|| sūrye turaṅge navacandraghasre jyeṣṭhākhyakṛṣṇe bhṛguvārayuktam || tattvaprayogaḥ ṣaḍaharṣasaṇjñaṃ likhitaṃ suhetoḥ bhavatīha dehi || bhūyāt (N2), iti paramarahasyāṃ śrīrāmacaṃdraviracitāyāṃ tatvayogabiṃdu samāptaḥ || śubhamastu | saṃvat 1841 || bhādau śudha 15tnīo vesarva śake rārāma rāma cha (D), iti śrī pāramahaṃsyāṃ śrī rāmacaṃdraviracitāyāṃ tatvayogaviduḥ samāptaḥ śubhaṃ bhūyāt || || atarlakṣyaṃ bahi dṛḍhir nirmeṣomeṣa varjitaḥ saiṣāśāṃbhavīmudrā sarvata,n treṣugopitā 1 aṃtark ..... (U1), iti śrī rāmacaṃdraparamahaṃsaviracitas tatvabiṃduyogasamāptaḥ || śrī śubhaṃ bhavatu || śrīsītārāmārpaṇamastuḥ || idaṃ pustakaṃ || śake 1805 || vikramārka saṃmat || 1140 || jayanām asaṃvatsare || udagayaṇe || griṣmaṛtau? || vaiśālhemāse || kṛṣṇapakṣe || tithau 23 || bhānuvāsare || prathamayāmye || śrī kṣetra avaṃtikāyāṃ || śrī mahārudramahākālasaṃnidhāne na saṃpūrṇaṃ || lekhanaṃ ānaṃt? suta bābājoo rājadherakareṇa likhyate || yādṛśaṃ pustakaṃ dṛṣtvā tādṛsaṃ likhitaṃ mayā || yadi śuddhaṃ aśuddho cā mama doṣo na dīyate ||1|| śrīrāma || cha || (U2)

Sentence omitted in englishL.

By this person the stabilization of the gaze shall be performed. The posisiton shall be made stable. The breath shall be stabilized. Such discipline has been stated by the accomplished one. When by means of mind and breath the natural bliss appears through ones own true nature, it is called natural Yoga (sahajayoga. Within Rājayoga the name cakravarttī is given [to it]. Thus concludes the Yogatattvabindu, composed by Srī Ramachandra Paramahaṃsa.
